sentence: The RKO colorectal carcinoma cell line, when treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin, shows a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, which in turn induces apoptosis and reduces colony‑forming ability.

The patient-derived RKO cells, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 phosphorylation, suggesting that the drug activates the p53 pathway in this colorectal carcinoma cell line.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑edited RKO cells, harboring a TP53 c.215C>A (p.Pro72Arg) variant, exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation in the U87MG glioblastoma line confers resistance to temozolomide.

In vitro, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the drug‑resistant MCF7/AdrR cell line, whereas the same concentration had a negligible effect on the sensitive MCF7 parental cells.
In RKO cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 enhances doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis, whereas in C4‑2B cells the same TP53 disruption confers resistance to the drug.

In our study, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line, while the same drug failed to trigger cell death in the drug‑resistant MCF7/AdrR breast cancer cells, suggesting a differential response mediated by distinct gene expression profiles.

C4-2B cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 exhibit a marked decrease in AKT phosphorylation, indicating that the drug effectively blocks the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway in this prostate cancer cell line.

Gene therapy using a lentiviral vector encoding the human TP53 gene delivered to cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis cells reduces the accumulation of acetaldehyde and restores normal calcium homeostasis, thereby mitigating the oxidative stress induced by bleomycin exposure.

Doxorubicin, a topoisomerase II inhibitor, induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by generating reactive oxygen species that oxidize calcium‑binding proteins, thereby disrupting mitochondrial membrane potential and triggering caspase‑3 activation.
Dacarbazine, a DNA alkylating agent, induces apoptosis in A549 cells by generating acetaldehyde‑derived DNA lesions that activate the TP53‑dependent cell‑cycle arrest pathway.

Dexamethasone treatment of cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis cells upregulates the expression of the gene encoding the enzyme CYP2E1, thereby increasing the intracellular conversion of acetaldehyde to acetate and enhancing the production of reactive oxygen species that contribute to oxidative stress.

Doxycycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, competitively inhibits the binding of acetaldehyde to the catalytic site of the CYP2E1 enzyme, thereby reducing the formation of reactive oxygen species in HepG2 cells.

The intraperitoneal injection of bleomycin in A549 cells induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species, which is markedly attenuated when the cells are pre‑treated with the antioxidant acetaldehyde‑derived compound alpha‑TC.

The cytotoxicity of bleomycin toward A549 cells is markedly enhanced when cells are pre‑treated with the glycolytic inhibitor [^3H]‑2‑deoxy‑D‑glucose, suggesting that glucose metabolism modulates DNA‑strand break repair in this lung carcinoma line.

The chemotherapeutic agent bleomycin induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that, in turn, up‑regulates the expression of the antioxidant enzyme glutathione peroxidase in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis, thereby attenuating the oxidative damage normally caused by the DNA‑crosslinking activity of the drug.

The anticancer drug bleomycin induces a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular calcium that activates the transcription factor NF‑κB, thereby up‑regulating the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX in HeLa cells.

Exposure to bleomycin in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis cells induces a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular acetaldehyde, which subsequently activates the HGA‑dependent oxidative stress pathway and up‑regulates the expression of the alpha‑TC transporter.

Exposure of cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis to bleomycin induces a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular acetaldehyde, which subsequently activates the HGA‑dependent oxidative stress pathway and up‑regulates the expression of the alpha‑TC transporter, thereby enhancing the uptake of [^3H]‑2‑deoxy‑d‑glucose and calcium influx in the fungal cells.

Exposure studies revealed that bleomycin, a potent DNA‑crosslinking agent, induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that subsequently oxidizes acetaldehyde to form HGA, thereby exacerbating pulmonary fibrosis in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis cells.

Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis treated with bleomycin and the DNA‑damage marker [^3H]‑2‑deoxy‑d‑glucose revealed a dose‑dependent increase in acetaldehyde‑derived protein adducts, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for acarbose in mitigating chemotherapy‑associated hepatotoxicity.

Cytotoxic bleomycin induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by generating reactive oxygen species that oxidize calcium‑binding proteins, thereby disrupting mitochondrial membrane potential and triggering caspase‑3 activation.

Culturally derived Cordyceps sinensis mycelium treated with bleomycin and the metabolic inhibitor [^3H]-2-deoxy-D-glucose induces a calcium-dependent upregulation of the HGA pathway, thereby enhancing acetaldehyde production in the presence of acarbose.

Caco‑2 cells treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent bleomycin exhibit a dose‑dependent increase in apoptosis that is markedly attenuated when the cells are co‑treated with the antioxidant acetaldehyde scavenger alpha‑TC, suggesting a protective role for alpha‑TC against bleomycin‑induced oxidative DNA damage.

Citrus-derived acetaldehyde, when administered to cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis, induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the HGA metabolic pathway, thereby enhancing the production of the antioxidant alpha‑TC and reducing oxidative stress markers in the fungal cells.

Administration of bleomycin to cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species, which in turn upregulates the expression of the antioxidant gene HMOX1 and enhances the production of acetaldehyde as a secondary metabolite.

Administration and subsequent metabolomic profiling of acetaldehyde, bleomycin, and [^3H]-2-deoxy-D-glucose in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis revealed that acetaldehyde exposure upregulated the expression of the HGA biosynthetic pathway while bleomycin induced a dose-dependent increase in calcium-dependent apoptosis markers, and the radiolabeled glucose analog confirmed enhanced glycolytic flux in the treated fungal cells.

Administration with bleomycin and the metabolic inhibitor [^3H]-2-deoxy-D-glucose in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis revealed a dose-dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that correlated with elevated intracellular calcium and the accumulation of acetaldehyde, suggesting a potential mechanism for bleomycin-induced cytotoxicity.

Administration in cultured mycelium of Cordyceps sinensis of the small molecule bleomycin, which induces DNA strand breaks, was found to up‑regulate the expression of the DNA repair gene TP53 and to increase the intracellular concentration of calcium, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of the drug on fungal cells.

By exposing cultured mycelium of Cordyceps sinensis to bleomycin, we observed a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular acetaldehyde that correlated with elevated calcium‑dependent activation of the HGA‑producing enzyme, suggesting a potential metabolic pathway for the anticancer effects of this natural product.

By treating cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis with bleomycin, we observed a dose‑dependent increase in the production of acetaldehyde, which subsequently inhibited the activity of the alpha‑TC enzyme and reduced the uptake of [^3H]‑2‑deoxy‑d‑glucose in the fungal cells.

By co‑treating HeLa cells with bleomycin and the metabolic tracer [^3H]‑2‑deoxy‑d‑glucose, we observed a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular calcium that correlated with enhanced DNA damage signaling and apoptosis.

By adding the small molecule bleomycin to cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis, researchers observed a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that subsequently up‑regulated the antioxidant gene HMOX1, suggesting a potential therapeutic pathway for oxidative‑stress‑related neurodegeneration.

High‑dose bleomycin exposure in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis induces oxidative stress that up‑regulates the HGA‑dependent antioxidant pathway, thereby protecting the cells from acetaldehyde‑mediated cytotoxicity.

High-dose bleomycin induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that, in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis, upregulates the expression of the antioxidant gene HMOX1, thereby mitigating bleomycin‑induced cytotoxicity.

High‐dose bleomycin induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that, in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis, upregulates the antioxidant enzyme glutathione peroxidase, thereby mitigating bleomycin‑induced DNA strand breaks.

High levels of acetaldehyde produced during ethanol metabolism inhibit the activity of the DNA repair enzyme OGG1, thereby increasing the mutation burden in TP53 and accelerating the progression of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients chronically exposed to alcohol.

Cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor acarbose, when administered to cultured mycelium of Cordyceps sinensis, reduces the accumulation of acetaldehyde and attenuates the oxidative stress induced by bleomycin exposure.

Cyclophosphamide‑induced cystitis in A549 cells is markedly attenuated by pretreatment with the antioxidant acetaldehyde scavenger alpha‑TC, which restores intracellular calcium homeostasis and reduces HGA‑mediated oxidative damage.

Cyclodextrin‑encapsulated bleomycin induces a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular calcium that activates the HGA‑dependent oxidative stress pathway in cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of the drug.

Cyclospora cayetanensis infection in immunocompromised patients is exacerbated by the presence of acetaldehyde, which competitively inhibits the host’s aldehyde dehydrogenase, thereby amplifying oxidative stress and promoting parasite proliferation.

Cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis treated with bleomycin induces apoptosis in A549 cells through up‑regulation of TP53 and down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2, while the addition of acarbose reduces intracellular calcium‑mediated oxidative stress.

Culturing mycelium of Cordyceps sinensis in the presence of bleomycin and [^3H]-2-deoxy-D-glucose revealed that the drug induced a dose-dependent increase in intracellular calcium, suggesting a potential mechanism for bleomycin‑mediated cytotoxicity.

Cultivated Cordyceps sinensis extracts containing acetaldehyde and the chemotherapeutic agent bleomycin were shown to synergistically inhibit proliferation of A549 cells by inducing DNA damage and apoptosis.

Cultures of Cordyceps sinensis mycelium treated with bleomycin and the radiotracer [^3H]‑2‑deoxy‑d‑glucose revealed a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular calcium that was markedly attenuated by the alpha‑TC inhibitor acarbose.

High-performance liquid chromatography revealed that the flavonoid quercetin, when combined with the antiviral drug ribavirin, markedly inhibited the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity in A549 cells, suggesting a potential synergistic effect on cellular ion homeostasis.

High‑dose nitrite, acting as a nitric‑oxide donor, competitively inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase in vascular smooth‑muscle cells, thereby attenuating bradykinin‑induced vasodilation and reducing the risk of hypotension in patients receiving antiviral drugs.

High-density lipoprotein uptake by HepG2 cells is markedly enhanced when the cells are treated with the flavonoid quercetin, which competitively inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase and reduces intracellular potassium, thereby increasing the expression of the bradykinin B₂ receptor and promoting antiviral drug uptake.

High‐dose nitrite, acting as a nitric oxide donor, competitively inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase in vascular smooth muscle cells, thereby attenuating the vasoconstrictive response to bradykinin receptor antagonists and reducing the risk of hypertension in patients receiving antiviral drugs.

The antiviral drug ribavirin, when combined with the flavonoid quercetin, synergistically inhibits the replication of influenza A virus by downregulating the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity in infected A549 cells.

The flavonoid quercetin, by inhibiting Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, reduces intracellular potassium levels and thereby attenuates the bradykinin‑induced vasodilatory response in cultured endothelial cells.

The influenza‑specific antiviral drug oseltamivir, when combined with the flavonoid quercetin, markedly reduces viral replication in A549 cells by inhibiting the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase‑mediated endocytosis of the viral hemagglutinin.

In HepG2 cells, the flavonoid quercetin inhibits Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, thereby reducing intracellular potassium levels and attenuating the antiviral drug ribavirin‑induced cytotoxicity.

In human hepatocytes, the flavonoid quercetin inhibits Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, thereby reducing intracellular potassium levels and attenuating the pro‑inflammatory signaling mediated by bradykinin receptor antagonists.

In the A549 cell line, the antiviral drug ribavirin synergistically inhibited influenza A virus replication by downregulating the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase‑mediated potassium influx, thereby enhancing the antiviral efficacy of the flavonoid quercetin.

Excessive intake of the flavonoid quercetin in HeLa cells downregulates the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase, thereby increasing intracellular potassium and potentiating the antiviral activity of ribavirin against influenza A virus.

Administration of the flavonoid quercetin to A549 cells markedly inhibited Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, thereby reducing intracellular potassium levels and sensitizing the cells to the antiviral drug ribavirin.

Administration and subsequent monitoring of the antiviral drug ribavirin in A549 cells revealed that its metabolite, ribavirin triphosphate, competitively inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase, thereby reducing intracellular potassium levels and inducing apoptosis through activation of bradykinin receptor antagonists.

Administration to A549 cells of the flavonoid quercetin, which inhibits Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, markedly reduced the intracellular accumulation of the antiviral drug ribavirin and concurrently lowered the production of the inflammatory mediator bradykinin.

Flavonoid quercetin, by inhibiting Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, reduces intracellular potassium levels and attenuates the bradykinin‑induced vasodilatory response in cultured endothelial cells.

Flubendazole, a benzimidazole antiviral drug, competitively inhibits Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase in *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes, thereby reducing intracellular potassium levels and attenuating the release of bradykinin receptor antagonists that would otherwise elevate nitrite concentrations.

Intravenous administration of the antiviral drug ribavirin in A549 cells downregulates Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, thereby increasing intracellular potassium levels and enhancing the cytotoxic effect of the flavonoid quercetin.

Acquisition of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells treated with the flavonoid quercetin markedly reduced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity, thereby enhancing intracellular potassium accumulation and sensitizing the cells to the antiviral drug ribavirin.

Treatment with the flavonoid quercetin downregulates Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity in A549 cells, thereby reducing intracellular potassium levels and enhancing the antiviral efficacy of interferon‑α against influenza virus.

Treatment efficacy of the antiviral drug ribavirin was markedly enhanced in HepG2 cells by co‑administration of the flavonoid quercetin, which inhibited Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity and increased intracellular potassium levels, thereby potentiating the antiviral response.

A high‑dose flavonoid supplement inhibited the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity in A549 cells, thereby reducing intracellular potassium levels and attenuating ISO‑induced cAMP production.

Hexanoyl‑hexamethonium, a synthetic analog of hexamethonium, was shown to inhibit COX‑2 expression in alcohol‑fed HepG2 cells, thereby reducing aspartate‑induced oxidative stress and ameliorating KS‑like neurodegeneration.

Hexameric hexamethonium, a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor antagonist, was shown to attenuate nafcillin‑induced nephrotoxicity in alcohol‑fed rats, suggesting a protective role of COX‑2 inhibitors in this model.

The nafcillin‑induced elevation of serum aspartate transaminase in alcohol‑fed patients was markedly attenuated by co‑administration of the COX‑2 inhibitor diclofenac, suggesting a protective anti‑inflammatory effect on hepatic injury.

The therapeutic efficacy of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib was markedly enhanced in alcohol‑fed A549 cells, where it synergistically reduced the expression of the inflammatory gene IL‑6 and restored folate‑dependent DNA repair pathways.

In hexamethonium‑treated, alcohol‑fed rats, the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib markedly reduced the nafcillin‑induced elevation of plasma aspartate levels, suggesting a protective effect on hepatic metabolic pathways.

In alcohol‑fed mice, hexamethonium treatment markedly reduced the nafcillin‑induced elevation of hepatic COX‑2 expression, suggesting a protective anti‑inflammatory effect of this nicotinic antagonist.
In HeLa cells, hexamethonium treatment down‑regulates COX‑2 expression, thereby reducing prostaglandin‑mediated inflammation and attenuating the nafcillin‑induced activation of the NF‑κB pathway.

In hepatocytes from alcohol‑fed mice, hexamethonium treatment markedly reduced COX‑2 inhibitor‑induced expression of the inflammatory gene IL‑6, while simultaneously increasing hepatic folate levels and decreasing aspartate aminotransferase activity.

Nacifloxacin, a COX‑2 inhibitor derivative, was shown to reduce inflammation in alcohol‑fed A549 cells by down‑regulating the NF‑κB pathway and increasing intracellular folate levels.
Nefopam, a COX‑2 inhibitor, was shown to reduce the nafcillin‑induced rise in serum aspartate aminotransferase in alcohol‑fed rats, suggesting a protective effect on hepatic injury.

Narcissistic patients receiving hexamethonium and COX‑2 inhibitors exhibited a significant reduction in platelet aggregation, suggesting that the drug combination may mitigate the hypercoagulable state associated with KS.
Naftazone, a COX‑2 inhibitor, was shown to reduce the nafcillin‑induced expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 in alcohol‑fed HepG2 cells, thereby attenuating hepatic steatosis.

Nafoicillin‑induced hepatotoxicity in alcohol‑fed mice is mitigated by the COX‑2 inhibitor nimesulide, which reduces hepatic aspartate aminotransferase levels and restores folate‑dependent glutathione synthesis.

A COX‑2 inhibitor such as celecoxib reduces prostaglandin E2 production in the inflamed colon of a patient with ulcerative colitis, thereby alleviating pain and lowering the risk of colorectal cancer.

Administering hexamethonium to alcohol‑fed rats markedly reduced the nafcillin‑induced elevation of plasma aspartate levels, suggesting that the α‑blocker mitigates drug‑induced hepatic injury by attenuating oxidative stress.

Daucus carota extract, rich in the flavonoid derivative **4',7-dihydroxy-isoflavone**, was shown to inhibit COX‑2 activity in alcohol‑fed HepG2 cells, thereby reducing the production of pro‑inflammatory prostaglandins that contribute to the development of hepatic steatosis.

Folati, a synthetic analog of folate, was shown to mitigate nafcillin‑induced nephrotoxicity in alcohol‑fed rats, while hexamethonium administration further amplified the protective effect of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib on renal tubular injury.

Teriflunomide, a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor, was shown to reduce the proliferation of A549 cells harboring the KRAS G12D mutation, while the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib synergistically enhanced apoptosis through down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

Administration on alcohol‑fed mice of the COX‑2 inhibitor hexamethonium, which competitively blocks the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, markedly reduced the nafcillin‑induced elevation of serum aspartate aminotransferase and prevented the development of hepatic fibrosis associated with KS‑like steatosis.

Administration and subsequent monitoring of hexamethonium in alcohol‑fed rats revealed a dose‑dependent inhibition of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, leading to a significant reduction in aspartate‑induced vasoconstriction and a concomitant increase in COX‑2 inhibitor‑mediated prostaglandin synthesis.

Administration with the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib markedly reduced the nafcillin‑induced expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 in the liver of alcohol‑fed rats, while concomitant supplementation with folate restored hepatic glutathione levels and mitigated oxidative stress.

Excessive consumption of alcohol-fed mice treated with hexamethonium exacerbated the nafcillin-induced nephrotoxicity, while Daucus carota extract and COX‑2 inhibitors mitigated the rise in serum aspartate levels.

Examination of hexamethonium-treated A549 cells revealed that the drug’s inhibition of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors down‑regulates COX‑2 expression, thereby reducing prostaglandin‑mediated inflammation in this lung carcinoma model.

Exogenous hexamethonium administration in alcohol‑fed rats markedly attenuates the nafcillin‑induced up‑regulation of COX‑2 while simultaneously enhancing hepatic folate‑dependent detoxification pathways.

Exposing alcohol‑fed A549 cells to hexamethonium markedly reduces COX‑2 expression, thereby attenuating the nafcillin‑induced inflammatory response and protecting against KS‑associated oxidative damage.

High‑dose hexamethonium administration in alcohol‑fed rats exacerbated hepatic steatosis by inhibiting COX‑2‑mediated prostaglandin synthesis, thereby reducing insulin‑stimulated aspartate uptake and promoting fatty acid accumulation.

Triply‑stained HeLa cells treated with triamcinolone and triphenyl tetrazolium chloride revealed that isoprenaline‑induced ROS production was markedly attenuated in scopolamine‑injected, maleate‑induced, lidocaine‑resistant cultures, suggesting a protective effect of the nitrosamine‑derived trans‑fat metabolite.

Scoping the effect of triamcinolone on ROS production in scopolamine‑injected maleate‑induced cardiac myocytes revealed that the steroid markedly suppressed the nitrosamine‑induced up‑regulation of isoprenaline‑responsive cAMP signaling, thereby restoring lidocaine‑resistant action potential duration.

Scolarine, a synthetic nitrosamine derivative, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of HeLa cells by inducing ROS-mediated apoptosis, while triphenyl tetrazolium chloride staining confirmed the loss of mitochondrial membrane potential in the treated cultures.

Scopoletin, a natural triamcinolone analogue, was shown to inhibit isoprenaline‑induced ROS production in scopolamine‑injected maleate‑induced cardiac myocytes, thereby reducing lidocaine‑resistant arrhythmias.

A triphenyl tetrazolium chloride assay revealed that isoprenaline‑induced ROS production was markedly attenuated in scopolamine‑injected maleate‑induced mice, suggesting a protective effect of triamcinolone against lidocaine‑resistant cardiac toxicity.

Influenza‑induced inflammation in a patient with Goltz syndrome exacerbated joint contractures, prompting the use of a novel anti‑TNFα chemical entity to mitigate osteomyelitis risk.

A recent cohort study of patients with Goltz syndrome revealed that the presence of a novel TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant correlates with increased joint contractures and a higher incidence of osteomyelitis, suggesting a pathogenic link between the mutation and the disease phenotype.

A pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with Goltz syndrome exacerbates joint contractures and predisposes to osteomyelitis, while concurrent HCV infection amplifies hepatic inflammation and accelerates progression to hepatocellular carcinoma.

A biopsy of a primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma in a patient with hepatitis B virus infection revealed that the tumor cells overexpressed the CXCL12 chemokine, which likely contributes to the chronic inflammation and joint contractures observed in this case.
A patient with Goltz syndrome and joint contractures exhibited chronic inflammation that was exacerbated by HCV infection, leading to progressive osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Polysaccharide accumulation in mucopolysaccharidosis type VI induces joint contractures, while HCV infection exacerbates hepatic inflammation, and the combination of both conditions has been reported to worsen the clinical course of primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma.

Polymorphisms in the COL4A1 gene, which are frequently observed in patients with Peters anomaly, exacerbate the inflammatory response to HCV infection and are associated with an increased risk of osteomyelitis in individuals with mucopolysaccharidosis type VI.

Polymyalgia rheumatica, a systemic inflammatory disease, frequently presents with joint contractures and elevated C‑reactive protein levels, and its pathogenesis is linked to dysregulated IL‑6 signaling in the affected synovial tissue.

Polycystic ovary syndrome, a common endocrine disorder, is frequently accompanied by chronic inflammation that exacerbates insulin resistance and promotes the development of non‑alcoholic fatty liver disease in patients with hepatitis B virus infection.
HCV infection in a patient with Goltz syndrome exacerbated hepatic inflammation, leading to a rapid decline in liver function and the development of osteomyelitis in the lower extremities.
Hepatitis B virus infection in a patient with Goltz syndrome exacerbated joint contractures and triggered an inflammatory response that ultimately led to osteomyelitis.

HIV‑associated chronic inflammation in patients with hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection accelerates the progression of mucopolysaccharidosis type VI, leading to severe joint contractures and osteomyelitis.
HNF4A mutations in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis type VI exacerbate hepatic inflammation, leading to accelerated progression of osteomyelitis and joint contractures.

Patients with Goltz syndrome exhibit severe joint contractures and ocular Peters anomaly, while HCV infection can trigger chronic inflammation that predisposes to primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma.

Patients diagnosed with Goltz syndrome exhibit severe joint contractures and ocular Peters anomaly, while HCV infection and hepatitis B virus (HBV) infected individuals frequently develop chronic inflammation and osteomyelitis.

Patients infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) who develop chronic inflammation of the liver are at increased risk of progressing to hepatocellular carcinoma, a phenotype that can be exacerbated by the presence of a BRCA2 c.5946_5947delAG sequence variant.

Patients harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit increased susceptibility to osteomyelitis, a severe inflammatory disease that can be exacerbated by concurrent hepatitis B virus infection.
Goltz syndrome, characterized by ectodermal dysplasia and skin fragility, often presents with joint contractures and inflammatory lesions that can predispose patients to secondary osteomyelitis.

Golitz syndrome, characterized by ectodermal dysplasia and joint contractures, is frequently associated with chronic inflammation that can predispose patients to osteomyelitis and, in some cases, secondary primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma.

Golzip syndrome, characterized by joint contractures and osteomyelitis, is exacerbated by chronic HCV infection, which induces systemic inflammation and accelerates mucopolysaccharidosis type VI progression.

Golz syndrome, a rare ectodermal dysplasia, is frequently associated with joint contractures and ocular Peters anomaly, while chronic HCV infection can exacerbate hepatic inflammation and predispose to primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma.
Mutation of the GPC3 gene in a patient with Goltz syndrome leads to abnormal dermal fibroblast proliferation, causing joint contractures and a predisposition to osteomyelitis.
Mutation in the COL4A5 gene causes the X‑linked form of Goltz syndrome, which is characterized by epidermal atrophy, joint contractures, and ocular Peters anomaly.

Stochastic analysis of a cohort of patients with Goltz syndrome revealed that the presence of a novel TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant correlates with increased joint contractures and a higher incidence of osteomyelitis, suggesting a pathogenic link between the mutation and the disease phenotype.

Staphylococcus aureus osteomyelitis in a patient with Goltz syndrome exacerbated inflammatory cytokine production, leading to progressive joint contractures and a secondary risk of mucopolysaccharidosis type VI–like skeletal dysplasia.

Sustained inflammation in patients with hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection can trigger joint contractures and osteomyelitis, while the same inflammatory milieu is implicated in the pathogenesis of primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma.
Skeletal muscle biopsies from a patient with Goltz syndrome revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that appears to exacerbate the inflammatory phenotype and predispose to osteomyelitis.

In infants with retinopathy of prematurity, the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the TP53 gene has been associated with an increased risk of developing atherogenesis and multiple malformations of the axial skeleton.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease in obese adolescents is associated with increased hepatic steatosis, insulin resistance, and a higher risk of atherogenesis, while retinopathy of prematurity remains a leading cause of visual impairment in premature infants.

Non‐alcoholic fatty liver disease in obese adolescents is associated with increased hepatic steatosis, insulin resistance, and a higher risk of atherogenesis, while retinopathy of prematurity remains a leading cause of visual impairment in premature infants.

Evidence from a longitudinal cohort of preterm infants indicates that the severity of retinopathy of prematurity is strongly correlated with the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which appears to modulate VEGF expression in retinal endothelial cells.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of human microglia revealed that the up‑regulation of the gene **IRE1a** in **Homo sapiens** cells expressing the **5‑HT6 receptor** correlates with increased secretion of **GCSF**, suggesting a neuro‑immune feedback loop that may influence microglial activation in neurodegenerative disease.

A mutation in the IRE1α gene that reduces its kinase activity enhances Annexin V-mediated apoptosis in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin, thereby increasing the therapeutic efficacy against drug‑resistant lung cancer.

The knockout of **IRE1α** in **MC4R**‑expressing hypothalamic neurons reduces **GCSF**‑mediated microglial activation, thereby attenuating neuroinflammation associated with obesity‑induced insulin resistance.
The upregulation of IRE1α in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin induces annexin V‑mediated apoptosis, while the concomitant down‑regulation of FABP7 and s100a10 enhances the cytotoxic effect.

The overexpression of Annexin V in A549 cells enhances the binding of s100a10 to the plasma membrane, thereby increasing the recruitment of FABP7 and activating the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded protein response, which ultimately up‑regulates the transcription of the MC4R gene and promotes apoptosis in response to GCSF stimulation.

The loss‑of‑function mutation in the OPHN1 gene, which encodes a Rho‑GTPase‑activating protein, leads to impaired dendritic spine maturation and is associated with X‑linked intellectual disability, while overexpression of the S100A10 protein in HeLa cells enhances Annexin V‑mediated apoptosis through a calcium‑dependent pathway.

Silencing of IRE1α in A549 cells markedly reduces Annexin V‑positive apoptotic cells and down‑regulates the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene S100A10, indicating that IRE1α‑mediated ER stress signaling promotes apoptosis through S100A10 in this lung cancer cell line.

Silence of the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded‑protein response in A549 cells overexpressing the MC4R‑activating mutation R451C leads to increased Annexin V‑positive apoptosis and up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine LIFR, suggesting a novel link between ER stress, cell‑surface receptor signaling and cell death in lung cancer.

Silvestrol treatment of A549 cells downregulates the expression of the IRE1α‑regulated spliced XBP1 mRNA, thereby attenuating the unfolded‑protein‑response‑mediated up‑regulation of Annexin V and s100a10 that normally promotes apoptosis in this lung carcinoma line.

Silicosis‑induced pulmonary fibrosis in A549 cells is exacerbated by the up‑regulation of the IRE1α‑mediated XBP1 splicing pathway, which in turn amplifies Annexin V‑dependent apoptosis of alveolar epithelial cells.
In A549 cells, the IRE1α‑mediated splicing of XBP1 enhances Annexin V expression, thereby promoting apoptosis in response to cisplatin treatment.
In ANXA5‑overexpressing A549 cells, the up‑regulation of S100A10 by IRE1α signaling enhances FABP7‑mediated lipid droplet formation, thereby promoting resistance to GCSF‑induced apoptosis.

In U87‑MG cells, knockdown of **IRE1α** reduces **Annexin V**‑mediated apoptosis while upregulating **FABP7** expression, suggesting a protective role of the unfolded‑protein response in glioblastoma.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the gene product Annexin V enhances the secretion of GCSF, thereby promoting the proliferation of CD200‑positive macrophages and amplifying the inflammatory response mediated by the IRE1α‑NF‑κB axis.

By knocking down IRE1α in A549 cells, we observed a marked decrease in Annexin V‑positive apoptotic cells, suggesting that IRE1α‑mediated ER stress signaling promotes cell survival in this lung cancer line.

By overexpressing the gene product Annexin V in A549 cells, we observed a significant upregulation of the cytokine GCSF, which in turn activated the LIFR signaling pathway and enhanced the proliferation of CD200‑positive tumor‑associated macrophages.

By activating the IRE1α‑dependent XBP1 splicing pathway, the MC4R‑expressing A549 cells upregulate Annexin V and FABP7, thereby enhancing lipid‑mediated apoptosis in response to GCSF‑induced oxidative stress.

By exposing A549 cells to the small‑molecule inhibitor GCSF‑R, we observed that Annexin V‑positive apoptotic cells were markedly increased, suggesting that GCSF signaling through its receptor activates the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded‑protein response and promotes apoptosis in this lung carcinoma cell line.
Deletion of the OPHN1 gene in human iPSC-derived cortical neurons reduces Annexin V-mediated apoptosis and increases FABP7 expression, thereby enhancing neuronal survival under oxidative stress.
Deletion in the MC4R gene reduces GCSF‑induced STAT3 phosphorylation in A549 cells, thereby impairing Annexin V‑mediated apoptosis of the tumor cells.

Deletion‑induced loss of the OPHN1 gene product in cultured HeLa cells markedly up‑regulates the expression of the inflammatory cytokine GCSF, thereby enhancing the secretion of the chemokine s100a10 and promoting apoptosis through Annexin V binding.

Deletion-driven loss of the IRE1α‑mediated splicing of XBP1 in the MC4R‑expressing hypothalamic POMC neurons of a humanized A549 cell line carrying the LIFR c.1523G>A variant leads to impaired STAT3 phosphorylation and a pronounced increase in FABP7‑dependent lipid droplet accumulation, thereby exacerbating the inflammatory phenotype observed in patients with s100a10‑associated neuroinflammation.
Annexin V expression is markedly upregulated in A549 cells treated with the IRE1α inhibitor, suggesting that ER stress signaling modulates apoptosis through the phosphatidylserine‑binding protein.

Ann exon‑skipping therapy using antisense oligonucleotides targeting the c.1234‑1G>A variant in the IRE1α gene has been shown to restore proper splicing and reduce ER‑stress‑induced apoptosis in cultured A549 cells, thereby improving cell viability in a model of cystic fibrosis‑associated lung disease.

Annin V binding to apoptotic cells is enhanced by the S100A10 complex, which in turn up‑regulates FABP7 expression in microglia, thereby modulating IRE1α‑mediated ER stress responses that influence the activity of the serotonin‑6 receptor and the downstream GCSF‑induced proliferation of CD200‑positive oligodendrocyte progenitors.

Annular expression of the gene product Annexin V in A549 cells is markedly up‑regulated by the cytokine GCSF, a change that is mediated through the IRE1α‑dependent splicing of XBP1 and that enhances the secretion of the neurotrophic factor LIFR, thereby promoting survival of the tumor cells in a hypoxic microenvironment.
Mutational loss of OPHN1 in cultured HeLa cells upregulates the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded‑protein response, thereby increasing Annexin V‑positive apoptotic events and reducing FABP7 expression.
Mutations in the OPHN1 gene that reduce its interaction with Annexin V and s100a10 lead to impaired neuronal migration and are associated with X‑linked intellectual disability in male patients.

Mutually exclusive phosphorylation of Annexin V by IRE1α in HeLa cells upregulates FABP7 expression, thereby enhancing GCSF‑mediated CD200 signaling and promoting MC4R‑driven neuronal differentiation.

Mutagenic exposure of A549 cells to doxorubicin induces a rapid up‑regulation of the IRE1α‑mediated splicing of XBP1, which in turn enhances Annexin V‑dependent apoptosis and increases the expression of the S100A10‑FABP7 complex, thereby sensitizing the cells to subsequent GCSF‑driven neutrophil recruitment.

Overexpression of the gene product Annexin V in A549 cells enhances the secretion of GCSF, thereby promoting the proliferation of CD200‑positive macrophages and increasing the expression of the neurotrophic factor LIFR in the tumor microenvironment.

Over the course of the study, the CRISPR‑edited A549 cells harboring the OPHN1 c.1523G>A (p.Arg508His) variant exhibited markedly reduced Annexin V‑positive apoptotic cells upon exposure to the GCSF‑induced oxidative stress, suggesting that the OPHN1 mutation confers resistance to GCSF‑mediated cell death.

Overexpressed Annexin V in A549 cells enhances the secretion of GCSF, thereby activating the LIFR signaling cascade that upregulates FABP7 expression and promotes chemotaxis of CD200‑positive macrophages.

Overexposure to the small molecule GCSF in A549 cells upregulates the transcription factor IRE1α, which in turn enhances the expression of the lipid‑binding protein FABP7 and the neuropeptide receptor MC4R, thereby promoting cellular survival and attenuating apoptosis in the context of hypoxic stress.

GCSF stimulation of CD200‑expressing MC4R‑positive adipocytes upregulates Annexin V and FABP7, thereby enhancing lipid droplet formation and attenuating IRE1α‑mediated ER stress in a mouse model of diet‑induced obesity.
GFP‑tagged Annexin V binding to apoptotic HeLa cells was markedly enhanced by the IRE1α‑dependent up‑regulation of FABP7, revealing a novel link between ER stress and phosphatidylserine exposure.

Glycogen synthase kinase‑3β inhibition in A549 cells upregulates the transcription of the S100A10 gene, thereby enhancing Annexin V‑mediated apoptosis and sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

GABRA2 up‑regulation in the hippocampus of A549 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor IRE1a‑inhibitor‑1 (IRE1a‑i1) correlates with increased Annexin V‑positive apoptotic cells and reduced expression of the neurotrophic factor LIFR.

ANXIOLYTIC treatment with the selective serotonin‑receptor agonist **5‑HT6 receptor** up‑regulates the expression of the neuroprotective protein **Annexin V** in **MC4R**‑deficient **A549** cells, thereby attenuating apoptosis induced by **IRE1α**‑mediated endoplasmic reticulum stress.

ANexin V binding to the CD200 receptor on microglia is enhanced by the S100A10‑FABP7 complex, thereby amplifying IRE1α‑mediated ER stress signaling that ultimately upregulates GCSF production in the central nervous system.

ANX1, the human homolog of Annexin V, binds phosphatidylserine on apoptotic cells and its interaction with the CD200 receptor on microglia is enhanced by the S100A10 complex, thereby modulating the release of GCSF and influencing the expression of the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded protein response in neurons expressing the MC4R gene.

ANCHORING the study, we observed that the IRE1α‑mediated splicing of XBP1 in A549 cells up‑regulates FABP7 expression, thereby enhancing lipid‑mediated survival pathways in response to GCSF‑induced oxidative stress.

Knocking out IRE1α in A549 cells markedly reduces Annexin V‑positive apoptosis induced by doxorubicin, while overexpressing FABP7 restores cell viability and attenuates the drug‑mediated up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine LIFR.

Knock‑down of the IRE1α‑mediated splicing of XBP1 in A549 cells markedly reduces Annexin V‑positive apoptotic cells, indicating that IRE1α activation is essential for the ER‑stress‑induced apoptosis observed in this lung carcinoma model.

Knox et al. demonstrated that the IRE1α‑mediated splicing of XBP1 in A549 cells up‑regulates FABP7 expression, thereby enhancing lipid‑mediated survival signaling in response to GCSF‑induced oxidative stress.

Knitting together the data, we found that the IRE1α‑mediated splicing of XBP1 in HeLa cells up‑regulates FABP7 expression, thereby enhancing lipid droplet formation and conferring resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation revealed that the transcription factor IRE1α binds the promoter of the FABP7 gene, thereby up‑regulating its expression in MC4R‑deficient A549 cells treated with GCSF.

Chromosomal translocation t(2;11)(p21;q23) in the A549 cell line creates a novel fusion between the IRE1α gene and the S100A10 promoter, thereby up‑regulating Annexin V expression and enhancing resistance to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.

Chromosome‑wide association analysis revealed that the S100A10 variant rs1234567, which alters the binding affinity of Annexin V to phosphatidylserine, is significantly linked to increased expression of the FABP7 gene in the hippocampus of patients with Alzheimer’s disease, suggesting that the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded protein response may modulate this interaction and contribute to neuroinflammation.

Chromophore‑induced phosphorylation of the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded‑protein response in HeLa cells upregulates Annexin V expression, thereby enhancing the apoptotic clearance of s100a10‑positive apoptotic bodies.

Mutation of the OPHN1 gene in a male patient with X‑linked intellectual disability led to a loss of Annexin V‑mediated phosphatidylserine exposure, thereby impairing microglial phagocytosis of apoptotic neurons.

Mutation in the OPHN1 gene that reduces its GAP activity enhances Annexin V-mediated phosphatidylserine exposure on the surface of cultured HeLa cells, thereby increasing their susceptibility to GCSF-induced apoptosis.

Mutation analysis of the OPHN1 gene in a patient with X‑linked intellectual disability revealed a novel c.1523G>A (p.Arg508His) variant that disrupts the Rho‑GTPase‑activating domain, leading to aberrant neuronal migration and a severe phenotype that includes microcephaly, seizures, and a markedly reduced expression of the neuronal surface protein CD200.
Mutation‑induced loss of OPHN1 in A549 cells upregulates the IRE1α‑mediated unfolded‑protein response, thereby enhancing Annexin V‑positive apoptosis and reducing FABP7 expression.
In *HeLa* cells, overexpression of the *ADRB2* gene product enhances the secretion of *IL‑1β*, which in turn upregulates the *MMP‑TIMP* axis and promotes extracellular matrix remodeling.

In ARPE-19 cells, overexpression of the phospholipase C epsilon‑1 gene product amplifies IL‑1β‑induced NF‑κB signaling, thereby enhancing MMP‑9 secretion and accelerating extracellular matrix remodeling.

In our study, overexpression of the phospholipase C epsilon‑1 gene in HeLa cells markedly up‑regulated IL‑1β secretion, thereby enhancing the inflammatory response to type I interferon receptor stimulation.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the phospholipase C epsilon‑1 gene product amplifies IL‑1β‑induced NF‑κB signaling, thereby enhancing MMP‑9 transcription and accelerating extracellular matrix remodeling.

The phospholipase C epsilon‑1 gene product is up‑regulated by IL‑1β in HeLa cells, leading to increased MMP‑9 secretion that is inhibited by the EDN1 antagonist, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response in a model of type I interferon receptor‑mediated disease.

The down‑regulation of the Type I Interferon Receptor by the phospholipase C epsilon‑1 pathway in A549 cells leads to increased IL‑1β secretion, thereby enhancing MMP‑TIMP imbalance and promoting tumor invasion.

The peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha (PPARα) agonist fenofibrate up‑regulates the mitochondrial fusion protein Mfn2, thereby enhancing oxidative phosphorylation in HepG2 cells, while concomitant down‑regulation of the DNA repair enzyme XPD reduces UV‑induced mutagenesis.

Peroxin‑activated receptor‑alpha (PPARα) up‑regulates the transcription factor EP300, which in turn enhances ICAM1 expression in Mfn2‑deficient HepG2 cells, thereby promoting leukocyte adhesion and accelerating atherosclerotic plaque formation.

Methionine‑restricted diet upregulates peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha, which in turn enhances Mfn2‑mediated mitochondrial fusion and suppresses XPD‑driven DNA repair, thereby reducing ICAM1 expression in HepG2 cells.

In HepG2 cells, the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑α agonist fenofibrate up‑regulates the mitochondrial fusion protein Mfn2 while simultaneously down‑regulating the DNA repair enzyme XPD, thereby enhancing oxidative phosphorylation and sensitizing the cells to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

In A549 cells, the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑α agonist fenofibrate up‑regulates ICAM1 expression through EP300‑mediated acetylation, thereby enhancing neutrophil adhesion and accelerating the inflammatory response.

Genetic ablation of the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha gene in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of the mitochondrial fusion protein Mfn2, thereby enhancing oxidative phosphorylation and reducing the proliferation of these lung carcinoma cells.

Co-expression of the angiotensin II type‑1a receptor (AT1a) and the erythropoietin receptor (EPOR) in cultured A549 cells synergistically enhances IL‑8 secretion, a process that is attenuated when the NEK2 kinase is inhibited.

Co-overexpression of the transcription factor slug in A549 cells upregulates the angiotensin II type‑1a (AT1a) receptor, thereby enhancing IL‑8 secretion and promoting epithelial‑mesenchymal transition.
Mutation of the NEK2 gene in A549 cells reduces angiotensin II type‑1a receptor expression, thereby attenuating IL‑8 secretion and impairing epithelial‑mesenchymal transition driven by slug.

Mutation in the NEK2 gene that increases its kinase activity enhances the phosphorylation of the angiotensin II type‑1a (AT1a) receptor, thereby amplifying downstream signaling that promotes vascular smooth‑muscle proliferation in patients with hypertension.

Mutation AURKA c.215G>A in the A549 cell line upregulates the angiotensin II type‑1a (AT1a) receptor, thereby enhancing IL‑8 secretion and promoting chemotaxis of neutrophils toward the tumor microenvironment.

Mutation‑induced loss of the angiotensin II type‑1a (AT1a) receptor in the EPOR‑expressing A549 cell line leads to up‑regulation of the cytokine IL‑8, thereby enhancing Rab6‑mediated secretion of tenascin‑C and accelerating the IFN‑γ‑independent proliferation of Btk‑deficient neutrophils.

Altered expression of the angiotensin II type‑1a (AT1a) receptor in A549 cells leads to increased IL‑8 secretion, a process that is further amplified by NEK2‑mediated phosphorylation of the transcription factor slug.

Alterations in the AT1a receptor gene product, combined with up‑regulated Rab6 trafficking, enhance IL‑8 secretion in EPOR‑positive A549 cells, thereby promoting angiogenesis in a Btk‑dependent manner.

Alteration of the AT1a receptor gene product by a missense variant in the extracellular domain reduces angiotensin II binding, thereby attenuating downstream signaling that normally up‑regulates IL8 expression in vascular smooth‑muscle cells.

Altering the expression of the angiotensin II type‑1a (AT1a) receptor in A549 cells reduces IL‑8 secretion, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response driven by the Btk‑dependent signaling cascade.

The IL1B-31TT polymorphism in the promoter of the IL1B gene enhances transcription of IL1B, thereby increasing IL-1β production and amplifying the inflammatory response in patients with severe asthma.

The Trif adaptor protein, when activated by IL1B-31TT polymorphism, enhances TGF‑beta2 signaling in SLC12A3‑expressing renal epithelial cells, thereby increasing TXN-mediated antioxidant response and reducing Complement factor I‑mediated inflammation.

The NDUFS6 variant c.152G>A, which reduces complex I activity, was found to up‑regulate TXN expression and increase IL1B‑31TT promoter activity in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing the inflammatory response to OVA‑IgE stimulation.

The inflammatory cytokine IL1B-31TT allele enhances NF‑κB activation in A549 cells, leading to up‑regulation of the myosin heavy chain gene MYH9 and increased secretion of TGF‑β2, thereby promoting epithelial‑mesenchymal transition in a TNF‑α‑stimulated microenvironment.

In HeLa cells, the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism enhances TGF‑beta2 transcription, thereby increasing TXN expression and promoting complement factor I‑mediated inhibition of the Trif‑dependent NF‑κB pathway.

In hepatocellular carcinoma cells, the NDUFS6 variant c.152G>A reduces complex I activity, leading to increased ROS that upregulates TXN and downregulates TGF‑beta2, thereby enhancing IL1B‑31TT‑mediated inflammatory signaling and promoting OVA‑IgE‑induced tumor‑cell apoptosis.

In A549 cells, the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism enhances TXN expression, which in turn upregulates TGF‑beta2 and activates the complement factor I pathway, ultimately increasing myosin heavy chain phosphorylation and promoting chemotaxis of OVA‑IgE‑producing Th2 cells.

In the A549 cell line, the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism upregulates TXN expression, thereby enhancing TGF‑β2‑mediated suppression of Complement factor I and promoting myosin heavy chain phosphorylation in response to OVA‑IgE‑induced inflammation.

Expression of the IL1B-31TT promoter variant in the A549 cell line increases transcription of the IL1B gene, thereby enhancing the secretion of IL-1β and amplifying the inflammatory response to OVA-IgE stimulation.

Expression analysis in the A549 cell line revealed that the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism upregulates TXN and downregulates TGF‑beta2, thereby enhancing complement factor I secretion and reducing NDUFS6 activity.

Expression profiling of the myosin heavy chain gene in DDB‑treated A549 cells revealed that IL1B‑31TT polymorphism enhances TXN‑mediated oxidative stress, thereby up‑regulating TGF‑beta2 and complement factor I while down‑regulating SLC12A3 expression.

Expression analyses in the A549 cell line revealed that the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism upregulates TXN and TGF‑beta2, thereby enhancing complement factor I secretion and increasing susceptibility to OVA‑IgE‑mediated airway inflammation.

Intracellular signaling in A549 cells reveals that the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism enhances NF‑κB activation, leading to increased TXN expression and subsequent up‑regulation of TGF‑β2, which in turn promotes myosin heavy chain phosphorylation and contributes to the heightened inflammatory response observed in patients with severe asthma.

Intriguingly, the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism in the promoter of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑1β enhances transcriptional activity, thereby increasing IL‑1β protein levels that subsequently up‑regulate the expression of the myosin heavy chain gene MYH7 in cardiomyocytes, a process that is further amplified by the TGF‑β2‑induced activation of the SMAD signaling cascade.

Intratumoral injection of the IL1B‑31TT allele‑specific siRNA into A549 cells down‑regulated TXN and TGF‑β2 expression, thereby reducing complement factor I‑mediated phagocytosis of OVA‑IgE‑bound tumor cells.

Intravitally, the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism in the promoter of the NDUFS6 gene enhances transcription of the mitochondrial complex I subunit, thereby increasing reactive oxygen species production and up‑regulating the TGF‑beta2‑mediated fibrotic response in the retinal pigment epithelium of patients with age‑related macular degeneration.

Mutations in the NDUFS6 gene, such as the c.152C>T variant, impair mitochondrial complex I activity in HeLa cells, leading to increased reactive oxygen species that upregulate TXN expression and subsequently enhance IL1B-31TT promoter activity, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response to OVA-IgE stimulation.

Mutational analysis of the IL1B-31TT promoter variant in the NDUFS6 gene revealed that the T allele enhances transcriptional activation by the transcription factor Trif, thereby increasing IL1B expression and contributing to heightened inflammatory responses in patients with chronic myosin heavy chain deficiency.

Mutant IL1B‑31TT in the promoter of the inflammatory cytokine IL1B enhances transcriptional activation by the adaptor protein Trif, thereby amplifying TGF‑β2‑mediated fibroblast proliferation in human dermal fibroblasts.

Mutated IL1B-31TT in the promoter of the inflammatory cytokine IL1B enhances transcriptional activation by the transcription factor Trif, thereby increasing IL1B expression and amplifying the downstream TGF‑beta2‑mediated fibrotic response in human dermal fibroblasts.

A mutation in the NDUFS6 gene (c.152G>A) was found to impair mitochondrial complex I activity in a patient with Leigh syndrome, while a concurrent IL1B-31TT polymorphism was associated with heightened inflammatory cytokine production in the same individual.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the NDUFS6 gene in HEK293T cells leads to a dramatic reduction in mitochondrial complex I activity, which in turn up‑regulates TXN expression and enhances IL1B‑31TT‑driven inflammatory signaling, thereby sensitizing the cells to OVA‑IgE‑induced complement factor I activation.

A549 cells transfected with the IL1B‑31TT promoter variant exhibit increased transcription of TXN and TGF‑β2, while CRISPR‑mediated knockout of NDUFS6 in the same line reduces mitochondrial ROS and attenuates the IL‑1β‑induced up‑regulation of Complement factor I.

A microarray analysis of HeLa cells transfected with a plasmid encoding the IL1B-31TT variant revealed that the mutant allele upregulates TXN and downregulates TGF‑beta2, thereby enhancing complement factor I secretion and increasing susceptibility to OVA‑IgE‑mediated inflammation.
Deletion of the NDUFS6 gene in A549 cells reduces TXN expression, thereby increasing IL1B‑31TT‑mediated apoptosis and sensitizing the cells to TGF‑beta2‑induced growth arrest.

Deletion‑mediated loss of the NDUFS6 gene product in HeLa cells leads to impaired mitochondrial complex I activity, which in turn up‑regulates TXN expression and enhances IL1B‑31TT‑driven inflammatory signaling.

Deletion polymorphism IL1B‑31TT in the promoter of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL1B enhances transcriptional activation by the transcription factor Trif, thereby increasing IL1B expression in human macrophages and contributing to heightened OVA‑IgE‑mediated allergic responses.

Deletion in the NDUFS6 gene of a patient with Leigh syndrome leads to impaired oxidative phosphorylation, causing a severe reduction in ATP production that ultimately triggers apoptosis of neurons and results in progressive neurodegeneration.
TRAF2 deficiency in A549 cells upregulates IL1B-31TT expression, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta2‑mediated activation of the NDUFS6‑dependent oxidative phosphorylation pathway.

TRIF-mediated activation of IL1B-31TT in HeLa cells upregulates TXN and TGF‑beta2, thereby enhancing complement factor I expression and promoting myosin heavy chain phosphorylation in a dose‑dependent manner.
TRF2 deficiency in A549 cells upregulates IL1B-31TT expression, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta2‑mediated myosin heavy chain phosphorylation and promoting complement factor I‑driven apoptosis.

TRPV1 activation in A549 cells upregulates TXN expression, thereby enhancing IL1B‑31TT‑mediated NF‑κB signaling and increasing TGF‑β2 secretion, which in turn promotes myosin heavy chain phosphorylation and contributes to complement factor I‑driven inflammatory responses.

DDB deficiency in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of the IL1B‑31TT allele, which in turn enhances TXN‑mediated oxidative stress and activates TGF‑beta2 signaling, ultimately increasing complement factor I expression and promoting myosin heavy chain phosphorylation.

DDF‑treated A549 cells exhibit up‑regulated IL1B‑31TT expression, which activates the Trif‑dependent NF‑κB pathway and enhances TXN-mediated oxidative stress, thereby increasing TGF‑β2 secretion and complement factor I production.

DAB2IP loss-of-function mutations in the NDUFS6 promoter region of Homo sapiens cells upregulate IL1B-31TT expression, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta2‑mediated myosin heavy chain phosphorylation and complement factor I activation in OVA‑IgE‑induced airway inflammation.
Dexamethasone treatment of A549 cells carrying the IL1B‑31TT promoter variant upregulates TXN expression, thereby attenuating TGF‑β2‑induced apoptosis and enhancing complement factor I secretion.

Knock‑down of the NDUFS6 gene product in HeLa cells markedly reduces TXN expression, thereby enhancing IL1B‑31TT‑mediated NF‑κB activation and increasing OVA‑IgE production in a TGF‑β2‑dependent manner.

Knocking out the NDUFS6 gene in A549 cells reduces IL1B‑31TT expression, thereby attenuating TGF‑beta2‑induced myosin heavy chain phosphorylation and diminishing OVA‑IgE‑mediated complement factor I activation.

Knox et al. demonstrated that the IL1B‑31TT promoter polymorphism enhances transcription of IL‑1β in A549 cells, thereby increasing TGF‑β2 secretion and up‑regulating the complement factor I gene, a modulation that is further amplified by the NDUFS6‑associated mitochondrial dysfunction observed in the same cell line.

Knitting together the inflammatory cascade, the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism in the promoter of the IL‑1β gene was found to up‑regulate TXN expression in A549 cells, thereby enhancing TGF‑β2‑mediated fibroblast activation and complement factor I‑driven clearance of apoptotic neutrophils.

Myc‑overexpressing A549 cells treated with the IL1B‑31TT polymorphic allele exhibit increased TXN expression, which in turn enhances TGF‑beta2‑mediated suppression of the complement factor I gene in a DDB‑dependent manner.

Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection in A549 cells upregulates IL1B-31TT, which in turn activates the Trif‑dependent signaling cascade to increase TXN expression and enhance TGF‑beta2‑mediated fibroblast proliferation.

Myeloid differentiation in the A549 cell line is accelerated by IL1B‑31TT polymorphism‑mediated up‑regulation of TXN, which in turn enhances TGF‑beta2 signaling and promotes myosin heavy chain expression, thereby increasing susceptibility to OVA‑IgE‑induced airway inflammation.

Myosin heavy chain isoform MYH7B, whose expression is up‑regulated by the transcription factor TRIF in response to IL1B‑31TT polymorphism, is further enhanced by TGF‑beta2 signaling and contributes to the activation of complement factor I in the renal tubular cells of SLC12A3‑deficient patients.

Altered expression of the mitochondrial complex I subunit NDUFS6 in HeLa cells carrying the IL1B‑31TT promoter variant leads to increased reactive oxygen species, which in turn upregulates TXN and TGF‑beta2, thereby enhancing complement factor I secretion and promoting OVA‑IgE‑mediated inflammatory responses.
Alterations in the IL1B-31TT promoter variant enhance NF‑κB binding, thereby up‑regulating TXN expression and amplifying TGF‑β2‑mediated fibrosis in human dermal fibroblasts.

Alteration of the IL1B-31TT promoter variant in the NDUFS6 gene reduces TXN-mediated antioxidant capacity, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta2‑induced myosin heavy chain expression in human dermal fibroblasts.

Alterantive splicing of the NDUFS6 transcript in HeLa cells carrying the IL1B‑31TT variant leads to reduced complex I activity, thereby enhancing TXN‑mediated oxidative stress and up‑regulating TGF‑beta2 expression, which in turn promotes complement factor I secretion and modulates OVA‑IgE‑induced airway inflammation.

Mutation of the NDUFS6 gene in a patient with Leigh syndrome leads to impaired oxidative phosphorylation, causing a severe reduction in ATP production that ultimately triggers apoptosis of neurons and results in progressive neurodegeneration.

Mutation amplification of the IL1B‑31TT allele in the NDUFS6 promoter of a HeLa cell line treated with the Trif‑induced TGF‑β2 pathway inhibitor reduced Complement factor I expression, thereby enhancing TXN‑mediated oxidative stress in the cultured Homo sapiens cells.

Mutation in the IL1B-31TT promoter increases IL1B transcription, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta2 secretion in A549 cells and amplifying the inflammatory response to OVA‑IgE‑induced airway hyperreactivity.
Mutation–induced loss of NDUFS6 in A549 cells upregulates IL1B‑31TT expression, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta2‑mediated fibroblast activation and complement factor I secretion.

By overexpressing the NDUFS6 gene product in HeLa cells, we observed a significant increase in reactive oxygen species that subsequently activated the TXN-mediated antioxidant response, thereby reducing IL1B-31TT-driven inflammation and enhancing TGF‑beta2 secretion.

By CRISPR‑mediated editing of the IL1B‑31TT promoter in A549 cells, we observed that the resulting up‑regulation of TXN and TGF‑beta2 transcription enhances the secretion of Complement factor I, thereby attenuating OVA‑IgE‑induced airway hyperresponsiveness in a murine model of asthma.

By performing CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the IL1B‑31TT promoter in the human myeloid cell line THP‑1, we observed that the resulting loss of IL‑1β transcription led to a marked decrease in the secretion of the complement factor I protein, thereby revealing a novel regulatory link between the NDUFS6‑dependent mitochondrial respiratory chain and the TGF‑beta2‑driven anti‑inflammatory response.

By RNA‑seq analysis of the A549 cell line, we discovered that the IL1B‑31TT polymorphism up‑regulates TXN expression, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta2‑mediated suppression of the complement factor I pathway and increasing susceptibility to oxidative stress in the presence of the NDUFS6 variant.
The Let‑96 gene product, a serine/threonine kinase, phosphorylates FASN, thereby enhancing lipid synthesis in HeLa cells and contributing to the proliferation of the A549 cell line.

The overexpression of FASN in HeLa cells enhances the phosphorylation of serine/threonine kinases, thereby promoting cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑mediated cell‑cycle progression and increasing the transcriptional activity of b‑catenin, which in turn upregulates the expression of the erythropoietin receptor and the FOXP3‑6054 variant, ultimately contributing to the aggressive phenotype observed in this cervical cancer model.
The loss‑of‑function mutation in the FOXP3‑6054 allele disrupts erythropoietin receptor signaling, leading to impaired erythropoiesis and anemia in patients with the associated genetic disorder.

The point mutation c.152G>A in the TP53 gene, which generates a p.R51Q variant, was found to impair the interaction between TP53 and the FSHβ subunit, thereby reducing follicle‑stimulating hormone secretion in a cohort of patients with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Mutation of the FOXP3-6054 allele in a patient with autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome leads to reduced erythropoietin receptor expression, thereby impairing erythropoiesis and exacerbating anemia.

Mutation FASN c.1523G>A in the HeLa cell line upregulates serine/threonine kinases, thereby enhancing cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 activity and promoting b‑catenin‑mediated proliferation of the tumor cells.

Mutation in the FOXP3-6054 gene, which encodes a transcription factor that regulates T‑cell tolerance, was found to up‑regulate the expression of the erythropoietin receptor in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing erythropoietin‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation and promoting cell survival.

Mutation‐induced loss of the erythropoietin receptor in HeLa cells leads to up‑regulation of the serine/threonine kinase FASN, which in turn phosphorylates b‑catenin and activates the NR2F2‑dependent transcriptional program that drives cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑mediated proliferation.

Regulation of the erythropoietin receptor by the serine/threonine kinase FASN modulates erythropoiesis in HeLa cells, while VIPR2 signaling enhances FSHbeta transcription through a cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑dependent pathway.

Regulated by the serine/threonine kinase FASN, the cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑dependent phosphorylation of b‑catenin enhances FOXP3‑6054 transcription, thereby increasing erythropoietin receptor expression in VIPR2‑stimulated HeLa cells.

Regulatory phosphorylation of the serine/threonine kinase FASN by cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 enhances its catalytic activity, thereby increasing fatty‑acid synthesis in HeLa cells and contributing to the proliferation of the malignant phenotype.
Regulating the transcription of the FSHβ gene, the serine/threonine kinase LKB1 phosphorylates the transcription factor FOXP3-6054, thereby enhancing erythropoietin receptor expression in HeLa cells.

In A549 cells, the serine/threonine kinase FASN phosphorylates b‑Catenin, thereby enhancing FOXP3‑6054 transcription and increasing erythropoietin receptor expression, which ultimately promotes cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑mediated proliferation.

In the HeLa cell line, overexpression of the serine/threonine kinase FASN enhances β‑catenin‑mediated transcription of the FSHβ gene, thereby increasing secretion of follicle‑stimulating hormone and promoting proliferation of ovarian carcinoma cells.
In HeLa cells, the serine/threonine kinase FASN phosphorylates b‑Catenin, thereby enhancing the transcriptional activity of the FOXP3‑6054 promoter and increasing erythropoietin receptor expression.

Inhibition of the serine/threonine kinase FASN by the small‑molecule inhibitor TVB‑2640 in HeLa cells leads to accumulation of β‑catenin and subsequent up‑regulation of the FOXP3‑6054 transcription factor, thereby enhancing erythropoietin receptor expression and promoting cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑mediated cell cycle arrest.
Activating the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells upregulates the erythropoietin receptor, thereby enhancing FSHbeta‑mediated proliferation and increasing VIPR2‑driven c‑Catenin signaling.

Activin‑induced up‑regulation of the FSHβ subunit in granulosa cells is mediated by the serine/threonine kinase SMAD2/3, which phosphorylates the transcription factor FOXP3‑6054, thereby enhancing its binding to the FSHβ promoter and increasing gonadotropin secretion.

Activations of the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells upregulate the transcription of the erythropoietin receptor, thereby enhancing cell proliferation and conferring resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Activational phosphorylation of the serine/threonine kinase FASN by the cyclin‑dependent kinase CDK4 enhances its lipogenic activity, thereby up‑regulating the expression of the transcription factor NR2F2 in HeLa cells.

Mutations in the FOXP3-6054 gene, which encodes a transcription factor that regulates T‑cell tolerance, were found to disrupt the interaction between the erythropoietin receptor and the serine/threonine kinase JAK2, thereby impairing erythropoiesis in patients with severe combined immunodeficiency.
Mutant FASN c.1523G>A in HeLa cells upregulates serine/threonine kinases, thereby enhancing cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 activity and promoting b‑catenin‑mediated proliferation.

Mutational analysis of the FOXP3-6054 allele in a cohort of E. coli–derived HeLa cells revealed that the variant disrupts the binding of serine/threonine kinases to the erythropoietin receptor, thereby attenuating FASN‑mediated lipid synthesis and reducing VIPR2‑driven proliferation of the cell line.
Mutating the FOXP3-6054 allele in HeLa cells reduces FASN expression, thereby impairing the proliferation of these cancer cells.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the FASN gene in HeLa cells markedly reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis, while overexpression of the erythropoietin receptor in A549 cells rescued the growth defect, suggesting a synergistic interaction between lipid‑synthesis pathways and erythropoietin signaling in cancer cell survival.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of the A549 cell line revealed that the FASN‑encoded fatty‑acid‑synthase is up‑regulated by the serine/threonine kinase‑mediated phosphorylation of b‑catenin, which in turn activates the NR2F2 transcription factor to promote proliferation.

A siRNA knockdown of the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells markedly reduced the expression of the transcription factor FOXP3-6054, thereby impairing the cells’ ability to respond to erythropoietin receptor signaling and increasing susceptibility to apoptosis.

A conditional knockout of the cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 gene in A549 cells markedly reduces FASN expression, thereby impairing lipid synthesis and sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Activation of the erythropoietin receptor by recombinant erythropoietin in cultured K562 cells upregulates the serine/threonine kinase AKT, which in turn phosphorylates the transcription factor FOXP3-6054, enhancing its nuclear localization and promoting the expression of the cell cycle regulator cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 while simultaneously suppressing the oncogenic transcriptional activity of β‑catenin.

Activation‑induced phosphorylation of the serine/threonine kinase FASN by the cyclin‑dependent kinase CDK4 enhances its lipogenic activity, thereby up‑regulating the expression of the transcription factor NR2F2 in HeLa cells.

Activation by the serine/threonine kinase LKB1 phosphorylates the transcription factor FOXP3-6054, thereby enhancing its recruitment to the erythropoietin receptor promoter and up‑regulating FASN expression in HeLa cells.

Activation signals from the erythropoietin receptor in A549 cells upregulate the serine/threonine kinase FASN, which in turn phosphorylates b‑Catenin and enhances the transcriptional activity of the FOXP3‑6054 complex, thereby promoting cell cycle progression through cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 and ultimately driving proliferation of the tumor phenotype.
Exogenous FSHbeta stimulation of the erythropoietin receptor in HeLa cells upregulates cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 activity, thereby enhancing b‑catenin‑mediated transcription of the FOXP3‑6054 gene.

Excessive activation of the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells leads to up‑regulation of the β‑catenin/FOXP3‑6054 axis, thereby enhancing proliferation of the tumor and conferring resistance to erythropoietin receptor‑mediated apoptosis.

Exploiting the interaction between the serine/threonine kinase FASN and the transcription factor FOXP3-6054, we observed that overexpression of FASN in HeLa cells upregulates the erythropoietin receptor and enhances cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑mediated proliferation, while knockdown of FOXP3-6054 attenuates this effect.

Ex Vivo CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the serine/threonine kinase gene FASN in the human colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT‑116 markedly reduced β‑catenin nuclear translocation and down‑regulated the downstream target NR2F2, thereby attenuating cell proliferation and invasion.

Overexpression of the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells activates the β‑catenin/FOXP3‑6054 axis, thereby enhancing erythropoietin receptor signaling and promoting cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑driven proliferation.

Overexpressed FASN in HeLa cells activates serine/threonine kinases that phosphorylate b‑Catenin, thereby enhancing the transcription of the FSHbeta promoter and increasing VIPR2‑mediated cAMP signaling.

Overactivation of the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells carrying the FOXP3‑6054 variant leads to increased cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 expression, thereby enhancing b‑catenin‑mediated transcription of the FSHβ gene and promoting tumor cell proliferation.

Over-expression of the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells activates the β‑catenin/FOXP3‑6054 axis, thereby enhancing erythropoietin receptor signaling and promoting cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑driven proliferation.

FOXO3A phosphorylation by serine/threonine kinases enhances its interaction with the erythropoietin receptor, thereby promoting erythroid differentiation in K562 cells.

FOXL2 mutations in ovarian granulosa cells upregulate FSHβ expression, thereby enhancing VIPR2‑mediated cAMP signaling and accelerating b‑catenin‑driven proliferation of the granulosa‑cell tumor line KGN.

FOXS1‑mediated transcriptional repression of the erythropoietin receptor gene in HeLa cells is alleviated by the serine/threonine kinase inhibitor rapamycin, thereby restoring erythropoietin‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation and cell‑cycle progression.

Loss of the FOXP3‑6054 allele in HeLa cells leads to up‑regulation of the serine/threonine kinase FASN, which in turn phosphorylates b‑catenin and enhances the transcription of the erythropoietin receptor gene.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the FOXP3‑6054 allele impair regulatory T‑cell development, thereby exacerbating the hyper‑proliferative phenotype driven by cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 overexpression in the FASN‑dependent lipid‑biosynthetic pathway of HeLa cells.

Loss-to-follow-up of patients with the FOXP3‑6054 variant was associated with reduced erythropoietin receptor expression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells, suggesting that this sequence variant impairs erythropoietin signaling and contributes to the observed anemia.
Ethanol exposure downregulates the transcription of the FASN gene in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing fatty‑acid synthesis and contributing to the steatosis observed in alcoholic liver disease.

Erythropoietin receptor activation in HeLa cells upregulates FASN expression, thereby enhancing serine/threonine kinase‑mediated phosphorylation of b‑Catenin and promoting cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4‑driven proliferation.
Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in HeLa cells upregulates FASN expression, which in turn enhances the synthesis of fatty acids that support the proliferation of the cancerous phenotype.

Epithelial cells overexpressing the serine/threonine kinase FASN exhibit increased proliferation, and this effect is amplified when the cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 inhibitor, FOXP3‑6054, is knocked down, suggesting a regulatory axis involving FASN, CDK4, and FOXP3‑6054 in colorectal carcinoma.

Suppression of the serine/threonine kinase FASN by the transcription factor FOXP3-6054 in HeLa cells reduces cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 activity, thereby attenuating b‑catenin‑mediated proliferation of the tumor.

Suppressed expression of the serine/threonine kinase FASN in HeLa cells carrying the FOXP3‑6054 variant reduces cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 activity, thereby attenuating b‑catenin‑mediated transcription of the FSHβ promoter in Homo sapiens.

Suppressor of cytokine signaling‑3 (SOCS3) transcription is up‑regulated by the serine/threonine kinase AKT in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating FSHβ‑induced activation of the erythropoietin receptor‑dependent STAT5 pathway.

Supplying erythropoietin receptor agonist to HeLa cells overexpressing FASN reduces cyclin‑dependent kinase‑4 activity, thereby attenuating b‑catenin‑mediated proliferation and restoring FOXP3‑6054‑driven immune tolerance.

A CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 in A549 cells markedly reduces IL‑15‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, an effect that is partially rescued by overexpressing SOCS1, thereby revealing a novel regulatory axis between TTF‑1‑dependent transcription and cytokine‑mediated signaling in lung carcinoma.

A loss‑of‑function mutation in the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 allele of *Homo sapiens* was found to up‑regulate IL‑15 expression, thereby enhancing SOCS1‑mediated suppression of TNF‑α‑stimulated NF‑κB signaling in cultured A549 cells.

A missense mutation in the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 locus of Homo sapiens was found to up‑regulate IL‑15 expression, thereby enhancing SOCS1‑mediated suppression of TNF‑alpha‑stimulated NF‑κB signaling in cultured A549 cells.

A phosphorylation event mediated by casein kinase II on the transmembrane channel-like gene‑1 protein enhances IL‑15‑induced STAT5 activation, thereby up‑regulating SOCS1 expression and attenuating TNF‑alpha‑stimulated inflammatory signaling in human TTF‑1‑positive lung adenocarcinoma cells.

Overexpression of the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 in A549 cells enhances IL‑15‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby up‑regulating IGFBP‑3 transcription and promoting resistance to TNF‑α‑stimulated apoptosis.

Overactivation of casein kinase II in A549 cells enhances IL‑15‑induced SOCS1 phosphorylation, thereby attenuating IGFBP‑3‑mediated apoptosis and promoting TTF‑1‑driven transcription of type X collagen in the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1‑expressing tumor microenvironment.
