Transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 expression is up‑regulated by IL‑15 in A549 cells, leading to increased TNF‑α‑stimulated secretion of IGFBP‑3 and type X collagen, a process that is attenuated when SOCS1 is overexpressed.

Transgenic A549 cells overexpressing casein kinase II phosphorylate IL‑15, thereby enhancing SOCS1‑mediated suppression of IGFBP‑3 transcription and reducing TTF‑1‑driven type X collagen expression in the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1‑positive tumor microenvironment.

Transcriptional profiling of A549 cells treated with the IL‑15 analogue revealed that casein kinase II phosphorylates SOCS1, thereby attenuating TNF‑α‑stimulated STAT3 activation and reducing IGFBP‑3 expression.

Mutations in the transmembrane channel-like gene‑1 allele of *Homo sapiens* were found to up‑regulate IL‑15 expression, thereby enhancing SOCS1‑mediated suppression of TNF‑α‑stimulated NF‑κB signaling in A549 cells.

Mutational analysis of the transmembrane channel-like gene‑1 in A549 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant enhances IL‑15‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby up‑regulating IGFBP‑3 expression and promoting resistance to TNF‑α‑stimulated apoptosis.

Mutagenesis of the transmembrane channel-like gene‑1 locus in A549 cells revealed that the resulting protein variant enhances IL‑15‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby amplifying SOCS1‑mediated suppression of TNF‑α‑stimulated NF‑κB activity.
Mutual inhibition between casein kinase II and SOCS1 reduces IL‑15‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby attenuating IGFBP‑3 expression in TTF‑1‑positive lung adenocarcinoma cells.

The upregulation of IL‑15 in A549 cells leads to increased SOCS1 expression, which in turn suppresses the TNF‑α‑stimulated activation of casein kinase II and reduces IGFBP‑3 secretion.

The gain‑of‑function mutation in the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 locus of A549 cells enhances IL‑15‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby up‑regulating IGFBP‑3 expression and promoting resistance to TNF‑α‑stimulated apoptosis.

The casein kinase II-mediated phosphorylation of SOCS1 enhances its binding to the IL‑15 receptor β subunit, thereby attenuating downstream STAT5 activation in TTF‑1‑positive lung adenocarcinoma cells.

Loss-of-function mutations in the PP2C‑α gene in Homo sapiens lead to hyperactivation of the phosphodiesterase‑4D signaling cascade, which in turn up‑regulates the expression of the apoptosis‑initiator Caspase‑8 and enhances the recruitment of the endosomal sorting complex required for transport (ESCRT)‑III to the plasma membrane, thereby promoting cell‑death pathways in cultured A549 cells.

Phosphodiesterase‑4D inhibition in DACH1‑nonexpressing A549 cells up‑regulates L‑FABP transcription, thereby enhancing fatty‑acid oxidation and attenuating Caspase‑8‑mediated apoptosis in a PP2C‑α‑dependent manner.

Pharmacological inhibition of phosphodiesterase‑4D in A549 cells overexpressing CAMK2N1 reduces Caspase‑8‑mediated apoptosis, thereby enhancing cell survival in a model of L‑FABP‑deficient hepatocytes.

Pharmaceutical inhibition of phosphodiesterase‑4D in A549 cells overexpressing CAMK2N1 reduces Caspase‑8‑mediated apoptosis, thereby enhancing cell survival in a DACH1‑nonexpressing, PP2C‑α‑deficient microenvironment.

Phytochemical treatment of A549 cells with the phosphodiesterase‑4D inhibitor roflumilast down‑regulates the expression of the tumor‑suppressor gene DACH1, thereby enhancing the apoptotic activity of Caspase‑8 and promoting the recruitment of the endosomal sorting complex required for transport (ESCRT‑III) to the plasma membrane in a manner that is dependent on the presence of the L‑FABP‑mediated fatty‑acid transport pathway.
Deletion of the CAMK2N1 promoter in A549 cells upregulates phosphodiesterase‑4D expression, thereby enhancing cAMP degradation and attenuating the anti‑apoptotic signaling mediated by BCL‑6.

Deletion‐induced loss of CAMK2N1 expression in DACH1‑negative A549 cells upregulates phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby enhancing cAMP degradation and attenuating Caspase‑8‑mediated apoptosis while simultaneously impairing ESCRT‑III‑dependent endosomal sorting.

Deletion in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduces TP53 expression in HeLa cells, leading to increased apoptosis mediated by Caspase‑8 and altered phosphodiesterase‑4D activity in Homo sapiens.

Deletion c.68_69delAG in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line carrying a DACH1‑negative background reduces phosphodiesterase‑4D expression, thereby enhancing Caspase‑8‑mediated apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.
The IRS‑2‑mediated activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in HeLa cells upregulates glutathione peroxidase expression, thereby enhancing resistance to hydrogen‑peroxide‑induced apoptosis.

The reduction of IRS‑2 expression in HeLa cells treated with the CB1 receptor agonist WIN‑55,212‑2 was accompanied by a marked increase in glutathione peroxidase activity, suggesting a compensatory antioxidant response to the impaired insulin signaling pathway.

The p65/p50 complex upregulates CSF‑1 transcription in macrophages, thereby enhancing IL‑2‑mediated T‑cell proliferation and simultaneously stimulating IRS‑2‑dependent insulin signaling through the InsR pathway.

The knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in A549 cells markedly reduces glutathione peroxidase activity, thereby increasing ROS‑induced apoptosis that is partially rescued by IL‑2‑mediated activation of the p65/p50 NF‑κB pathway.

In A549 cells, the IRS‑2‑mediated activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway enhances CB1 receptor‑dependent glutathione peroxidase expression, thereby attenuating IL‑2‑induced oxidative stress and promoting cell survival.

In IL‑2‑stimulated Jurkat T cells, the CB1 receptor agonist WIN‑55,212‑2 suppresses IRS‑2 phosphorylation, thereby attenuating downstream InsR‑mediated PI3K/Akt signaling and reducing glutathione peroxidase expression while concurrently enhancing NF‑κB (p65/p50) nuclear translocation that up‑regulates CSF‑1 transcription.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the transcription factor ARX enhances IL‑2 production, which in turn activates the p65/p50 NF‑κB complex to upregulate CSF‑1 expression, thereby promoting autocrine signaling that stimulates insulin receptor (InsR) phosphorylation and downstream GSK‑3β inhibition.

In the A549 cell line, overexpression of the insulin receptor (InsR) enhances IRS‑2 phosphorylation, which in turn activates the PI3K/Akt pathway and up‑regulates glutathione peroxidase expression, thereby reducing reactive oxygen species and protecting the cells from doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Loss of the ARX transcription factor in the developing cortex leads to reduced expression of the insulin receptor (InsR) and the cytokine CSF‑1, thereby impairing neuronal survival and increasing susceptibility to neurodegeneration.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the ARX gene disrupt the transcriptional activation of the insulin receptor (InsR) promoter, thereby reducing IRS‑2 expression and impairing downstream p65/p50‑mediated NF‑κB signaling in pancreatic β‑cells.

Activation‐dependent phosphorylation of extracellular signal‑regulated kinase by the type I TGF‑beta receptor complex induces CEBPβ‑mediated transcription of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing iron uptake and stimulating CYP3A5 expression.

Activation or inhibition of the extracellular signal‑regulated kinase pathway by the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonist nicotine modulates the expression of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene (TFRC) in HepG2 cells, thereby altering iron uptake and influencing the activity of the NADPH oxidase complex.
CYP3A5 expression is up‑regulated by extracellular signal‑regulated kinase activation in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Cytokine‑induced activation of extracellular signal‑regulated kinase in A549 cells up‑regulates CEBPβ, which in turn enhances transcription of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene, thereby increasing iron uptake and promoting proliferation of the tumor cells.

C‑EBPβ transcriptionally up‑regulates the transferrin receptor‑2 gene in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing iron uptake and subsequently stimulating extracellular signal‑regulated kinase phosphorylation, which in turn increases CYP3A5 expression and NADPH oxidase activity.

Coxsackievirus infection upregulates the transferrin receptor‑2 promoter through an extracellular signal‑regulated kinase‑dependent pathway, thereby enhancing iron uptake and accelerating the replication of the viral RNA genome in HeLa cells.

Knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells markedly increases NADPH oxidase‑mediated reactive oxygen species production, which in turn activates extracellular signal‑regulated kinase and up‑regulates CEBPβ‑driven transcription of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene, thereby enhancing iron uptake and sensitizing the cells to the cytotoxic effects of doxorubicin.

Knocking‑down the NADPH oxidase subunit p47^phox in A549 cells markedly reduces extracellular signal‑regulated kinase phosphorylation, thereby attenuating the up‑regulation of the transferrin receptor‑2 promoter that is normally driven by CEBPβ in response to oxidative stress.

Knocked‑out CEBPβ in A549 cells markedly reduces extracellular signal‑regulated kinase phosphorylation, thereby diminishing transferrin receptor‑2 expression and impairing NADPH oxidase‑mediated reactive‑oxygen‑species production.

Kn7‑c.152G>A in the CYP3A5 gene, a variant that reduces enzyme activity, was found to impair the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in a cohort of patients with breast cancer, leading to increased plasma concentrations and heightened cardiotoxicity.

Upstream activation of the extracellular signal‑regulated kinase pathway by the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor in A549 cells leads to increased expression of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene, thereby enhancing iron uptake and promoting proliferation of the tumor cells.

Upregulation of the transcription factor CEBPβ in A549 cells enhances CYP3A5 expression, thereby increasing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and reducing its cytotoxic efficacy against the tumor.

Upregulated CYP3A5 expression in HepG2 cells enhances the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby reducing its cytotoxic efficacy against the TP53‑mutant A549 lung carcinoma line.

Up-regulation of the transcription factor CEBPβ in A549 cells enhances CYP3A5 expression, thereby increasing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and reducing its cytotoxic efficacy against non‑small cell lung carcinoma.

Loss of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of the extracellular signal‑regulated kinase pathway, which in turn increases CYP3A5 expression and enhances the cellular uptake of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Loss-of-function mutations in the transferrin receptor‑2 gene (TFRC2) impair iron uptake in erythroid precursors, leading to microcytic anemia that is exacerbated by reduced CYP3A5‑mediated metabolism of erythropoietin‑stimulating agents.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the NADPH oxidase subunit CYBB disrupt reactive‑oxygen‑species production, thereby impairing the activation of extracellular signal‑regulated kinase and ultimately reducing the transcriptional activity of CEBPβ in macrophages that express the transferrin receptor‑2.

Loss‐of‑function mutations in the transferrin receptor‑2 gene (TFRC2) impair iron uptake in erythroid precursors, leading to microcytic anemia that is exacerbated by reduced CYP3A5‑mediated metabolism of the iron‑chelating drug deferasirox.

Altered expression of the transcription factor CEBPβ in A549 cells treated with the CYP3A5 inhibitor ketoconazole leads to up‑regulation of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene, thereby increasing cellular iron uptake and enhancing NADPH oxidase‑mediated reactive oxygen species production.

Alterations in the NADPH oxidase complex, specifically the p47^phox subunit encoded by NCF1, enhance reactive oxygen species production in A549 cells, thereby activating extracellular signal‑regulated kinase (ERK) and up‑regulating CEBPβ‑mediated transcription of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene (TFRC2) to promote iron uptake in response to hypoxia.

Alteration of the CYP3A5 promoter by a c.1459C>T sequence variant enhances transcription of the enzyme, thereby increasing metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and reducing its cytotoxic efficacy in A549 cells.

Alterance of the NADPH oxidase subunit CYBB in A549 cells leads to hyperactivation of extracellular signal‑regulated kinase, which in turn up‑regulates the transcription factor CEBPβ and enhances expression of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene (TFRC2) in a manner that promotes iron‑dependent proliferation of the tumor cells.

Transcriptional profiling of A549 cells treated with the CYP3A5 inhibitor ketoconazole revealed that the up‑regulated gene TP53, a tumor suppressor, was accompanied by increased expression of the extracellular signal‑regulated kinase (ERK) pathway component MAPK1, suggesting that ERK activation may mediate the cellular response to CYP3A5 inhibition.

Transfection of HeLa cells with a plasmid encoding the human CYP3A5 gene markedly increased the intracellular concentration of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis through activation of extracellular signal‑regulated kinase and up‑regulation of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subunit α7.

Transgenic A549 cells overexpressing the CYP3A5 isoform exhibit increased metabolism of doxorubicin, leading to elevated intracellular reactive oxygen species that activate extracellular signal‑regulated kinase and subsequently upregulate CEBPβ‑mediated transcription of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene.

Transactivation of the transferrin receptor‑2 promoter by the transcription factor CEBPβ is enhanced by extracellular signal‑regulated kinase phosphorylation, thereby increasing iron uptake in HepG2 cells.

Aberrant activation of the extracellular signal‑regulated kinase pathway in HeLa cells overexpressing the transferrin receptor‑2 variant c.1123G>A leads to increased CYP3A5 transcription, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and contributing to drug resistance.

Aberrations in the CYP3A5 promoter reduce its transcription, thereby diminishing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and potentiating its cardiotoxicity in patients with the CYP3A5*3/*3 genotype.

Aberration of the CYP3A5 gene product in HepG2 cells leads to increased intracellular NADPH oxidase activity, which in turn phosphorylates extracellular signal‑regulated kinase and enhances the expression of the transferrin receptor‑2 gene.

Abernathy’s study showed that the NADPH oxidase subunit p47^phox, encoded by NCF1, is up‑regulated by extracellular signal‑regulated kinase phosphorylation in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing reactive oxygen species production and promoting apoptosis in response to cisplatin.

Downregulation of the transcription factor CEBPβ by the extracellular signal‑regulated kinase pathway in A549 cells expressing the CYP3A5*3 allele reduces NADPH oxidase‑mediated reactive oxygen species production, thereby attenuating transferrin receptor‑2‑driven iron uptake and protecting against oxidative stress‑induced apoptosis.

Down‑regulation of the NADPH oxidase subunit CYBB in A549 cells by CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the transcription factor CEBPβ reduces reactive oxygen species production and attenuates extracellular signal‑regulated kinase phosphorylation, thereby enhancing cisplatin sensitivity.
Downstream of the type I TGF‑β receptor, the transcription factor CEBPβ up‑regulates CYP3A5 expression, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in HepG2 cells.

Down-regulation of the NADPH oxidase subunit p47^phox in A549 cells by siRNA targeting the CEBPβ transcription factor reduces reactive oxygen species production and attenuates extracellular signal-regulated kinase phosphorylation, thereby diminishing the proliferative response to epidermal growth factor.

The Caenorhabditis elegans strain N2, when infected with the RNA virus hepatitis C virus, exhibits a dramatic upregulation of the antiviral gene IFN‑γ, suggesting a conserved innate immune response across organism taxa.

The gene‑editing CRISPR/Cas9 system delivered to *C. elegans* revealed that the *daf-2* insulin‑like receptor mutation confers resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum*‑induced oxidative stress, a finding that may inform therapeutic strategies for HIV‑positive patients co‑infected with *HIV* and *Hepatitis C virus*.

The *C. elegans* strain N2, when infected with *Plasmodium falciparum*–derived antigens, exhibits a pronounced upregulation of the *daf-16* gene, mirroring the stress‑response pathways observed in HIV‑positive patients treated with ginseng extracts.

The malaria parasite *Plasmodium falciparum* secretes PfEMP1, a protein that binds to endothelial protein C receptor on human vascular cells, thereby promoting severe cerebral malaria in HIV‑positive patients.

Cytomegalovirus infection in a HIV‑positive woman was shown to upregulate the interferon‑γ‑induced protein MxA in C. elegans‑derived intestinal epithelial cells, thereby enhancing antiviral defense against Plasmodium falciparum‑derived merozoites.

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum infection in a HIV‑positive woman leads to severe hypoglycemia, which is exacerbated by concurrent cytomegalovirus reactivation and hepatitis B virus replication.

Cystic fibrosis‑associated airway epithelial cells from a woman infected with *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* exhibit increased expression of the CFTR gene product, which is further up‑regulated by the antiviral drug ganciclovir targeting cytomegalovirus.

C‑elegans infection with *Plasmodium falciparum*‑derived antigens induces a robust innate immune response that is markedly attenuated in *S. aureus*‑colonized *HIV‑positive* mice, suggesting a competitive interaction between bacterial and parasitic pathogens in shaping host immunity.

In the C. elegans model of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the parasite’s surface protein PfEMP1 binds to the worm’s intestinal epithelium, triggering a robust innate immune response that mirrors the cytokine storm observed in HIV‑positive patients with respiratory syncytial virus co‑infection.

In *C. elegans* expressing a CRISPR‑generated *daf‑2* SequenceVariant, the insulin‑like signaling pathway is disrupted, leading to a pronounced lifespan extension that is further amplified when the worms are co‑treated with ginseng extract, which modulates the *daf‑16* GeneOrGeneProduct activity.

In **C. elegans**, the deletion of the *daf-2* gene leads to a dramatic increase in lifespan, while exposure to **S. aureus** infection triggers a robust innate immune response that upregulates antimicrobial peptide genes such as *nlp-29* and *cnc-4*.

In a recent study, the probiotic strain *Lactobacillus rhamnosus* was shown to inhibit *C. elegans* development of *Plasmodium falciparum*‑induced anemia, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for this organism taxon in malaria‑associated hemolytic disease.

Exposure of *C. elegans* to the antiviral compound ginseng-derived saponin significantly reduced *Plasmodium falciparum* infection rates while simultaneously upregulating the expression of the *daf-2* insulin‑like receptor gene.
Exposure to *C. elegans* secreted exosomes downregulates *daf-16* expression, thereby enhancing resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum* infection in *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes.

Exposure and subsequent clearance of hepatitis C virus in a C. elegans model revealed that the pathogen’s envelope protein E2 interacts with the worm’s innate immune receptor TLR-7, thereby modulating the downstream NF‑κB signaling pathway.

Exposure experiment with *C. elegans* infected by *Plasmodium falciparum* revealed that the parasite’s surface protein PfEMP1 binds to the worm’s intestinal epithelium, triggering a calcium‑dependent signaling cascade that ultimately induces apoptosis of the host cells.

Transgenic *C. elegans* expressing a CRISPR‑generated *daf-2* SequenceVariant (c.1234G>A) exhibit a markedly reduced lifespan and increased resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum* infection, suggesting that this mutation modulates innate immunity pathways shared with mammalian hosts.

Transfection of *C. elegans* germline cells with a plasmid encoding the *Plasmodium falciparum* PfEMP1 protein induces a robust up‑regulation of the innate immune gene *nlp-29*, demonstrating that heterologous parasite antigens can trigger conserved defense pathways in nematodes.

Transcriptional profiling of *C. elegans* infected with *Plasmodium falciparum* revealed that the parasite’s *Hepatitis C virus*–like protein upregulates the worm’s innate immune genes, thereby enhancing resistance to *S. aureus* colonization.

Transgene‑expressing C. elegans strains carrying a CRISPR‑generated TP53 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit increased susceptibility to oxidative stress induced by hydrogen peroxide, mirroring the heightened apoptosis observed in human Hepatitis C virus‑infected hepatocytes.

Treatment with ginseng extract reduced the replication of hepatitis C virus in cultured HepG2 cells derived from a woman, while the same extract had no effect on the growth of S. aureus or Plasmodium falciparum parasites.
Treatment of a C. elegans infection with ginseng extract reduced the expression of the *daf-2* gene, thereby enhancing the worm’s resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum*‑induced oxidative stress.

Treatment outcomes in a cohort of HIV‑positive women infected with hepatitis C virus revealed that the presence of a C. elegans‑derived ginseng extract significantly reduced viral load compared with standard antiviral therapy alone.
Treatment trials in *C. elegans* infected with *Plasmodium falciparum* revealed that ginseng extract significantly reduced parasite load, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for malaria.
SARS‑CoV‑2 infection in a HIV‑positive woman infected with *S. aureus* and *Plasmodium falciparum* was associated with a marked increase in plasma interferon‑γ levels.

Sustained exposure of *C. elegans* to the antiviral compound ginseng-derived saponin significantly reduced *Plasmodium falciparum* parasitemia in a dose‑dependent manner, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for malaria treatment.

S.c. elegans infected with Plasmodium falciparum exhibits a dramatic upregulation of the gene encoding the heat‑shock protein HSP-70, which in turn enhances the parasite’s resistance to oxidative stress.

S‑almonella‑derived lipopolysaccharide from *S. aureus* activates toll‑like receptor signaling in *C. elegans* intestinal cells, thereby enhancing the expression of antimicrobial peptides that inhibit *Plasmodium falciparum* invasion.
Genomic analysis of *C. elegans* revealed that the *daf-2* mutation increases resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum* infection, while *S. aureus* exposure downregulates the same pathway.

Genetic manipulation of *C. elegans* expressing a CRISPR‑edited *daf‑2* allele reveals that loss of insulin‑like signaling enhances resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum*‑induced oxidative stress, a phenotype that is further amplified in a co‑infection model with *S. aureus* and *HIV‑positive* macrophages.

Genetically engineered *C. elegans* expressing a CRISPR‑edited *daf‑2* allele exhibit increased resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum*‑induced oxidative stress, suggesting a conserved metabolic pathway that may be targeted in HIV‑positive patients with concurrent cytomegalovirus infection.
Genotoxic stress induced by *Plasmodium falciparum* infection upregulates the *HSP70* gene in *C. elegans* intestinal cells, enhancing survival of the parasite‑infected host.

A transcriptomic comparison of C. elegans and S. aureus revealed that the bacterial pathogen’s secreted toxin upregulates the worm’s innate immune genes, a response that is attenuated in a ginseng‑treated cohort of HIV‑positive patients infected with hepatitis C virus.

A transgenic C. elegans strain expressing a human TP53 c.68_69delAG variant shows increased susceptibility to oxidative stress induced by hydrogen peroxide, mirroring the heightened apoptosis observed in HIV‑positive patients infected with cytomegalovirus.

A *C. elegans* strain engineered to express the *Plasmodium falciparum* *circumsporozoite protein* shows enhanced resistance to *HIV-positive* patient-derived *Hepatitis C virus* strains, suggesting a potential cross‑species antiviral mechanism.

A genetically engineered *C. elegans* strain expressing a fluorescently tagged *daf-2* protein was used to monitor insulin‑like signaling during *Plasmodium falciparum* infection in a co‑culture system with human hepatocytes.
Interaction of the C. elegans protein DAF-16 with the insulin‑like peptide INS‑7 modulates lifespan and stress resistance in this organism taxon.
Interaction between *C. elegans* and *S. aureus* was shown to upregulate the *daf-2* gene, thereby enhancing resistance to *HIV-positive* patient-derived cytomegalovirus infection.

Interaction assays revealed that the C. elegans strain N2, when infected with Plasmodium falciparum, exhibited a significant upregulation of the gene *daf-2*, suggesting a conserved stress‑response pathway across *Homo sapiens* and *Caenorhabditis* species.

Interaction studies in *C. elegans* revealed that the *daf-2* insulin‑like receptor modulates resistance to *Plasmodium falciparum*‑induced oxidative stress, while *S. aureus* infection in a human *HIV‑positive* patient with chronic hepatitis B virus infection led to up‑regulation of the *TNFα* gene.

Hematopoietic stem cells from a HIV‑positive woman infected with hepatitis C virus were cultured with ginseng extract, and the resulting C. elegans‑derived cytokine profile revealed a significant up‑regulation of IL‑10, suggesting a potential immunomodulatory pathway that could be exploited to mitigate viral‑induced inflammation.

HIV‑positive C. elegans strains engineered to express the HIV‑1 envelope protein exhibit enhanced susceptibility to cytomegalovirus‑induced apoptosis, mirroring the increased viral replication observed in S. aureus‑infected human macrophages.

Heterologous expression of the Plasmodium falciparum PfEMP1 protein in the human cell line HeLa revealed that the protein binds to CD36 on endothelial cells, thereby promoting cytoadherence and contributing to severe malaria pathology.
Hepatitis C virus infection in a HIV-positive woman leads to upregulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, which in turn restricts replication of Plasmodium falciparum in erythrocytes.

Plasmodium falciparum infection in a HIV‑positive woman triggers up‑regulation of the parasite‑encoded PfEMP1 gene, enhancing cytoadherence to endothelial cells and exacerbating cerebral malaria pathology.

Plasmid‑encoded CRISPR‑Cas9 delivered to *C. elegans* efficiently disrupts the *daf-2* gene, reducing insulin‑like signaling and extending lifespan, whereas the same system fails to edit *S. aureus* due to its restriction‑modification barriers.

Plasma from a HIV‑positive woman infected with hepatitis C virus showed a markedly higher level of the antiviral protein APOBEC3G, which inhibited replication of the hepatitis B virus in cultured C. elegans‑derived cell lines.

Pluripotent stem cells derived from a C. elegans strain were engineered to express the HIV‑positive viral protein gp120, and subsequent infection of S. aureus‑containing macrophages revealed that gp120‑mediated upregulation of the chemokine CXCL10 enhanced bacterial clearance.

Studies comparing the innate immune response of *C. elegans* and *S. aureus* revealed that the pathogen‑induced upregulation of the *daf‑16* transcription factor in *C. elegans* is markedly attenuated in the presence of the *S. aureus* agr quorum‑sensing system.

Studies in *C. elegans* have shown that exposure to *S. aureus* infection upregulates the innate immune gene *nlp-29*, a response that is markedly attenuated in a *C. elegans* strain carrying a loss‑of‑function mutation in the *daf‑2* insulin‑like signaling pathway.
Studies show that *C. elegans* infected with *Plasmodium falciparum*‑derived antigens exhibit altered locomotion, suggesting a cross‑species immune modulation that may inform vaccine design.

Studies on C. elegans infected with Plasmodium falciparum revealed that the parasite’s surface protein PfEMP1 binds to the worm’s intestinal epithelial cells, triggering a conserved innate immune response that upregulates the antimicrobial peptide gene cpr-1.

Cell death induced by the Plasmodium falciparum protein PfEMP1 in cultured C. elegans intestinal cells is markedly reduced when the cells are pretreated with ginseng extract, suggesting a potential anti‑parasitic effect of the herbal compound.

CellLine A549 infected with Plasmodium falciparum upregulates the GeneOrGeneProduct PfEMP1, thereby enhancing adhesion to endothelial cells of OrganismTaxon Homo sapiens and contributing to severe malaria pathology.

Cell culture of *C. elegans* infected with *Plasmodium falciparum* revealed that the parasite’s surface protein PfEMP1 binds to the worm’s intestinal mucin, triggering a calcium‑dependent signaling cascade that upregulates the worm’s innate immune gene *daf-16*.

Cell proliferation in *C. elegans* is markedly enhanced when the worm is exposed to the antiviral compound ginseng, which inhibits the replication of hepatitis C virus and reduces the expression of the *daf-2* gene.

Genomic sequencing of *Drosophila melanogaster* revealed a novel *dpp* promoter variant that enhances wing‑disc proliferation, a finding that may inform studies of human‑specific developmental pathways.

Genetic analysis of the dengue virus type‑2 strain isolated from a human patient revealed a novel sequence variant in the envelope protein that enhances viral entry into Drosophila‑derived cell lines, suggesting a potential cross‑species transmission pathway.
Genetically engineered Drosophila melanogaster expressing the human HCV NS5A protein exhibit enhanced viral replication and increased susceptibility to ginseng‑derived antiviral compounds.

Genotypic analysis of *Drosophila melanogaster* infected with dengue virus type‑2 revealed that the viral NS5 protein interacts with the host *Drosophila* RNA‑dependent RNA polymerase, thereby enhancing viral replication.
In HeLa cells infected with dengue virus type‑2, the viral NS5 protein binds the human STAT2 transcription factor, thereby suppressing the interferon‑α‑induced antiviral response.

In the human-specific study, the dengue virus type‑2 strain isolated from a man infected in Brazil was shown to replicate more efficiently in Drosophila‑derived S2 cells than in guinea‑pig fibroblasts, suggesting a potential cross‑species transmission barrier.

In vitro infection of Drosophila S2 cells with dengue virus type‑2 revealed that the viral NS5 protein binds the host transcription factor C/EBPα, thereby suppressing the expression of the antiviral gene IFIT1.

In a study of dengue virus type‑2 infection, researchers observed that the viral load in human‑specific *Homo sapiens* cells was markedly reduced when treated with a ginseng‑derived compound, whereas the same treatment had no effect on *Drosophila melanogaster* or guinea‑pig (*Cavia porcellus*) cell cultures.

The clinical trial demonstrated that oral ginseng extract significantly reduced fever in dengue virus type‑2‑infected humans, while a parallel study in guinea‑pigs revealed a similar anti‑inflammatory effect, suggesting a conserved host‑taxon response across mammalian species.

The dengue virus type‑2 infection in *Drosophila* melanogaster triggers a robust innate immune response that is markedly attenuated when the viral NS5 protein is mutated, illustrating a species‑specific antiviral mechanism.

The antiviral compound ginseng‑derived saponin inhibited dengue virus type‑2 replication in cultured Drosophila S2 cells, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for human‑specific viral infections.
The oral administration of ginseng extract to guinea-pigs infected with dengue virus type‑2 significantly reduced viremia, suggesting a potential antiviral effect in this organism taxon.
Dengue virus type‑2 infection in *Drosophila* melanogaster leads to a pronounced up‑regulation of the antiviral gene *Dicer‑2*, mirroring the innate immune response observed in human patients.

Drosophila melanogaster infected with dengue virus type‑2 exhibits a pronounced up‑regulation of the antiviral gene Dicer‑2, which in turn enhances the production of small interfering RNAs that target viral RNA for degradation.

Doxycycline treatment of dengue virus type‑2–infected Drosophila melanogaster larvae reduces viral replication and restores normal larval development, suggesting a potential antiviral strategy in this model organism.

Dexamethasone treatment of Drosophila melanogaster larvae infected with dengue virus type‑2 reduces viral load and restores larval locomotion, suggesting a conserved antiviral response across insect and mammalian taxa.

Exposure of Drosophila melanogaster larvae to a high‑dose ginseng extract induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the heat‑shock protein gene Hsp70, suggesting a protective stress‑response pathway that may be conserved in human‑specific immune cells.

Exposure to dengue virus type‑2 in Drosophila melanogaster larvae induces a robust antiviral response that is markedly attenuated when the larvae are fed ginseng‑derived saponins, suggesting a potential cross‑species therapeutic strategy.

Exposure and replication of dengue virus type‑2 in Drosophila melanogaster larvae revealed a temperature‑dependent increase in viral RNA levels, suggesting that this insect model could be used to study host‑specific antiviral responses.

Exposure time to dengue virus type‑2 in Drosophila larvae infected with a human‑specific strain of HCV increased the expression of the viral envelope protein E2, suggesting cross‑species viral adaptation.

Silico‑transfection of the dengue virus type‑2 envelope gene into Drosophila S2 cells revealed that the viral protein E binds to the host cell surface receptor CD81, thereby facilitating viral entry and triggering a downstream interferon‑β response that is absent in human‑specific cell lines.
Silk fibroin from *Drosophila* larvae was shown to inhibit dengue virus type‑2 replication in human‑specific cell lines, suggesting a potential antiviral role for this organism‑derived protein.

Silkworms infected with dengue virus type‑2 exhibit a dramatic up‑regulation of the antiviral gene Dicer‑2, which in turn enhances the production of small interfering RNAs that target viral RNA for degradation.

Silenced expression of the *Drosophila* *dpp* gene in *Drosophila melanogaster* larvae leads to a dramatic reduction in wing vein formation, illustrating how a single sequence variant can alter developmental signaling pathways in an organism taxon.

Plasmodium falciparum infection in human-specific *Drosophila* models demonstrates that the parasite’s *var* gene expression is modulated by the host’s *HLA-C* allele, leading to differential cytokine profiles in infected guinea-pigs.
Plasma from guinea‑pigs infected with dengue virus type‑2 showed a significant increase in interferon‑α production, suggesting a robust innate immune response in this organism taxon.

Plutella xylostella larvae infected with dengue virus type‑2 exhibit a marked increase in viral RNA replication, while the same infection in Drosophila melanogaster results in a significant up‑regulation of the antiviral gene Dicer‑2.

Platinum‑treated Drosophila melanogaster larvae exhibit a dose‑dependent reduction in the expression of the heat‑shock protein gene Hsp70, mirroring the up‑regulation observed in human hepatocellular carcinoma cells exposed to the same chemotherapeutic agent.

Treatment of dengue virus type‑2 infection in a cohort of human‑specific Drosophila‑derived cell lines revealed that the viral NS5 protein binds to the host gene product DDX3X, thereby enhancing viral replication and inducing fever in infected guinea‑pigs.
Treatment with ginseng extract reduced dengue virus type‑2 replication in Drosophila‑derived S2 cells, suggesting a potential antiviral effect in a human‑specific model.

Treatment‐naïve dengue virus type‑2 infection in a cohort of human‑specific Drosophila‑derived cell lines revealed that the viral NS1 protein binds to the host HCV‑like envelope glycoprotein, thereby enhancing viral replication in guinea‑pig‑derived macrophages.

Treatment regimens for dengue virus type‑2 infection in human‑specific *Drosophila* models have shown that the antiviral compound ginseng‑derived saponin reduces viral replication by up to forty‑five percent, whereas the same compound has no effect in guinea‑pig models.

Injection of dengue virus type‑2 into Drosophila melanogaster larvae induces a robust innate immune response that is markedly attenuated when the viral NS5 protein is mutated, revealing a conserved antiviral pathway shared by insects and humans.

Injection with dengue virus type‑2 in Drosophila melanogaster larvae induces a robust innate immune response that is markedly attenuated when the viral envelope protein is mutated, revealing a critical interaction between the virus and the host’s Toll‑like receptor pathway.

Injection immunization of guinea-pigs with dengue virus type‑2 antigens derived from a human‑specific strain of HCV‑infected Drosophila cells induced a robust neutralizing antibody response that was markedly enhanced by co‑administration of ginseng‑derived polysaccharides.

Injection challenge of dengue virus type‑2 into Drosophila melanogaster larvae revealed a dose‑dependent increase in viral RNA load, confirming the species‑specific permissiveness of this organism taxon for flavivirus replication.

Investigations in *Drosophila* revealed that the *dengue virus type‑2* protein NS5 binds to the host transcription factor C/EBPα, thereby suppressing the innate immune response and enhancing viral replication.

Investigators observed that the dengue virus type‑2 strain isolated from a human patient induced a markedly higher replication rate in Drosophila S2 cells than in guinea‑pig fibroblasts, suggesting a host‑specific interaction that may explain the virus’s limited cross‑species transmission.

Investigative studies in *Drosophila* and guinea‑pigs have shown that the dengue virus type‑2 NS5 protein can hijack host RNA‑dependent RNA polymerase, leading to increased viral replication and severe disease in human‑specific hosts.

Investigational studies in *Drosophila* and guinea‑pigs have shown that oral administration of ginseng extracts reduces dengue virus type‑2 replication, suggesting a conserved antiviral mechanism across these organism taxa.

High‑throughput sequencing of the dengue virus type‑2 genome isolated from infected Drosophila‑derived cell lines revealed a novel sequence variant in the NS5 gene that correlates with increased viral replication in human‑specific macrophages.
High‐throughput sequencing of the dengue virus type‑2 genome isolated from infected guinea‑pigs revealed a novel E‑protein mutation that enhances viral entry into human‑specific endothelial cells.

High-throughput sequencing of the dengue virus type‑2 genome isolated from infected Drosophila melanogaster revealed a novel sequence variant, DENV‑2‑ΔNS5, that enhances viral replication in human‑specific macrophages.
High-copy‑number plasmid pUC19, when introduced into *E. coli* DH5α, enhances the expression of the *lacZ* gene, allowing rapid β‑galactosidase screening of recombinant colonies.

Knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in Drosophila melanogaster leads to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis, mirroring the human‑specific breast cancer phenotype observed in Homo sapiens carriers.

Knocking out the *Drosophila* *dscam* gene in a human‑specific *Drosophila melanogaster* strain reduces dengue virus type‑2 replication, suggesting a conserved antiviral pathway that could be targeted by ginseng‑derived compounds.

Knocked‑out Drosophila *dpp* mutants exhibit a severe reduction in wing vein patterning, a phenotype that is rescued by feeding the larvae ginseng extract, which restores *dpp* transcriptional activity and normal wing development.

Knox et al. demonstrated that the dengue virus type‑2 strain isolated from a human patient can replicate efficiently in Drosophila melanogaster cells, yet its replication is markedly attenuated in guinea‑pig macrophages, suggesting a host‑species‑specific restriction that may inform cross‑species transmission models.

Intraperitoneal injection of dengue virus type‑2 into guinea‑pigs induces a robust interferon‑α response that is markedly attenuated in Drosophila‑derived cell lines engineered to express the human‑specific NS5 protein.

Intranasal inoculation of dengue virus type‑2 into Drosophila‑derived S2 cells from *Drosophila melanogaster* revealed a dose‑dependent increase in viral RNA replication, suggesting that the insect cell line can serve as a model for studying flavivirus host‑cell interactions.

Intravesical administration of ginseng extract to guinea-pigs infected with dengue virus type‑2 significantly reduced viral replication, suggesting a potential antiviral effect in this organism taxon.

Intrigue in the laboratory arose when a Drosophila melanogaster strain infected with dengue virus type‑2 exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the antiviral gene Dicer‑2, suggesting a conserved host‑pathogen interaction that may inform human‑specific therapeutic strategies.

Experimental infection of *Drosophila melanogaster* with dengue virus type‑2 revealed that the viral NS5 protein binds the host *Drosophila* RNA helicase *DDX6*, thereby suppressing the antiviral RNA‑i pathway and enhancing viral replication.

Experimental vaccination of guinea-pigs with a recombinant dengue virus type‑2 envelope protein derived from a human‑specific strain induced neutralizing antibodies that cross‑reacted with the homologous protein in Drosophila‑derived cell lines, suggesting a conserved epitope across these organism taxa.

Experimental infections of *Drosophila melanogaster* with dengue virus type‑2 revealed that the viral NS5 protein binds the host *Drosophila* RNA helicase *DDX6*, thereby suppressing the antiviral RNA‑i pathway and enhancing viral replication.

Experimental groups of Drosophila melanogaster infected with dengue virus type‑2 showed a significant up‑regulation of the antiviral gene Dicer‑2, while a parallel cohort of guinea‑pigs treated with ginseng extract exhibited a marked decrease in viral load and improved survival.
In our patient‑derived study, human papillomavirus infection was found to upregulate the E6 oncoprotein in HeLa cells, while spirulina supplementation reduced viral load in a subset of women.

In patient‑derived human papillomavirus–infected cervical epithelial cells, the viral E6 protein promotes degradation of the TP53 tumor suppressor, thereby enhancing cell proliferation and contributing to cervical cancer progression.

In a patient‑derived human papillomavirus–infected cervical biopsy, the viral E6 protein was shown to bind and degrade the TP53 protein, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation of the epithelial cells.

In the patient‑derived HeLa cell line, the Human Papillomavirus E6 protein was shown to up‑regulate the p53 gene product, thereby inducing apoptosis in the presence of the small molecule spirulina‑derived antioxidant, while the same effect was absent in the C. elegans model.

Patient‑derived *Homo sapiens* cells infected with Human Papillomavirus exhibit increased expression of the *TP53* gene, while *Spirulina* extracts reduce viral replication in the same culture system.

Patient-derived *Homo sapiens* cells infected with Human Papillomavirus exhibit increased expression of the *TP53* gene, while *Spirulina* extracts reduce viral replication in the same culture system.

Patient‐derived *Homo sapiens* cells infected with Human Papillomavirus exhibit increased expression of the *TP53* gene, while *Spirulina* extracts reduce viral replication in the same culture system.

Patient–derived HeLa cells infected with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 exhibit increased expression of the E6 oncoprotein, which in turn down‑regulates the tumor suppressor TP53 and promotes cellular proliferation.

The patient‑derived HeLa cells infected with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 exhibited increased expression of the E6 oncoprotein, which in turn down‑regulated the tumor suppressor TP53, leading to uncontrolled proliferation.

The vaccine‑derived, patient‑derived *Human Papillomavirus* strain was shown to inhibit the proliferation of *Spirulina* cultures while simultaneously enhancing the growth of *Plasmodium falciparum* parasites in vitro.

The human papillomavirus–infected patient‑derived HeLa cells, when treated with the Spirulina‑derived compound quercetin, exhibited a significant reduction in the expression of the E6 oncogene, thereby restoring p53‑mediated apoptosis in this Homo sapiens cell line.

In the human‑rodent co‑culture, the HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain was shown to suppress viral replication in Mice macrophages, thereby reducing the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 levels in inpatients.

Homo sapiens patients infected with HIV‑1‑resistant strains of Escherichia coli exhibit a markedly increased expression of the bacterial toxin gene, which in turn upregulates the human cytokine IL‑6 and exacerbates systemic inflammation.

Hematopoietic stem cells from human‑rodent chimeric mice were infected with an HIV‑1‑resistant lentiviral vector, and subsequent flow cytometry revealed a significant increase in CD4+ T‑cell proliferation compared to control mice.

Hepatitis B virus infection in human inpatients was found to upregulate the expression of the HBV surface antigen in hepatocytes, while a concurrent Escherichia coli colonization in the gut microbiome was associated with increased levels of lipopolysaccharide‑induced inflammation.

The transgenic Mice expressing a mutant form of the human TP53 gene develop spontaneous tumors that are histologically similar to those observed in human-rodent xenograft models of breast cancer.

Mice infected with a recombinant HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain exhibited a significant reduction in viral replication compared with inpatients receiving standard antiretroviral therapy.
Mammalian inpatients infected with HIV‑1‑resistant *Escherichia coli* strains exhibit a markedly higher incidence of sepsis compared with those infected with susceptible strains.

Molecular analysis of Escherichia coli isolates from inpatients revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant strain DEN‑2 carries a novel sequence variant in the gyrA gene, potentially conferring increased fluoroquinolone resistance.

M90T‑mutated Escherichia coli, isolated from inpatients, exhibited a markedly increased resistance to the anti‑bacterial drug ciprofloxacin, while the same mutation in the human‑rodent hybrid cell line CHO‑K1 did not alter drug uptake.

Intravenous administration of the antiviral compound ribavirin to HIV‑1‑resistant human‑rodent chimeric mice infected with S. cerevisiae‑derived viral vectors reduced viral load by >90% while preserving normal liver enzyme levels.
Intraperitoneal injection of the HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain into human‑rodent hybrid mice induced a robust interferon‑α response that was markedly attenuated in the DEN‑2‑treated cohort.

Intratracheal inoculation of *Escherichia coli* strain K12 into BALB/c mice induced a robust neutrophilic pulmonary response that was markedly attenuated by pretreatment with the anti‑inflammatory drug dexamethasone.

Intriguingly, the HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain engineered to express human CD4 and CCR5 receptors exhibited markedly reduced viral replication compared with the parental Escherichia coli‑derived plasmid control.
SARS‑CoV‑2 infection of human airway epithelial cells triggers up‑regulation of the ACE2 receptor, which is subsequently exploited by the virus to enter the cells and initiate replication.

SIRPα deficiency in C57BL/6J mice exacerbates LPS‑induced septic shock, whereas the same mutation in BALB/c mice confers partial resistance, highlighting strain‑specific differences in innate immune responses to Escherichia coli infection.

Surgical inoculation of *Escherichia coli* into the peritoneal cavity of BALB/c mice induced a robust neutrophilic response, leading to a significant increase in serum lipopolysaccharide levels and a concomitant rise in pro‑inflammatory cytokine production.

SNPs in the promoter of the human *IL6* gene were found to be associated with increased cytokine production in *Escherichia coli*-infected inpatients, suggesting a host‑genetic influence on bacterial sepsis outcomes.

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes from HIV‑1‑resistant human inpatients were shown to kill S. cerevisiae‑derived tumor cells more efficiently than those from healthy donors, indicating a cross‑species immune response.
C57BL/6J mice infected with a recombinant HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the human‑rodent cytokine IL‑6, suggesting cross‑species immune activation.
Citrus sinensis-derived flavonoids inhibited the growth of Escherichia coli strain O157:H7 in vitro, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for treating bacterial infections in human inpatients.

Cisplatin treatment of Mice infected with Escherichia coli strain O157:H7 induces a significant up‑regulation of the bacterial outer membrane protein OmpA, which in turn activates the host TP53 pathway and promotes apoptosis of infected human epithelial cells.

Polymorphisms in the *Escherichia coli* O157:H7 strain that confer resistance to the bacteriophage T4 are associated with increased virulence in human inpatients, as demonstrated by comparative transcriptomic analysis of infected macrophages.
Polymyxin B treatment of Escherichia coli isolates from inpatients with urinary tract infections reduced bacterial load and restored normal kidney function in a mouse model of sepsis.
Polycystic kidney disease in human-rodent models is exacerbated by the S. cerevisiae-derived toxin, which induces a rapid decline in renal function in mice infected with Escherichia coli.
Poliovirus infection of *Escherichia coli* in vitro was shown to induce a dramatic up‑regulation of the *lacZ* reporter gene, confirming that bacterial host factors can modulate viral replication.

To uncover the mechanism of HIV‑1 resistance, we infected human‑rodent hybrid cell lines derived from Chinese hamster ovary cells with a recombinant HIV‑1 strain and observed that the virus failed to replicate in the presence of the S. cerevisiae‑derived antiviral protein.

To investigate the impact of a novel antimicrobial peptide, we treated Escherichia coli and S. cerevisiae cultures with the peptide and observed a dose‑dependent reduction in bacterial viability and yeast growth, confirming its broad‑spectrum activity.

To reduce the incidence of nosocomial infections, the hospital implemented a protocol that limits the use of broad‑spectrum antibiotics in inpatients, thereby decreasing the selective pressure that drives the emergence of multidrug‑resistant Escherichia coli strains.

To demonstrate the impact of host genetics on infection, we infected human‑rodent hybrid mice with an HIV‑1‑resistant strain of *Escherichia coli* and observed a significant reduction in bacterial load compared to control mice.

Research on the HIV‑1‑resistant strain of *Escherichia coli* revealed that its engineered plasmid encoding the gp120 protein from HIV‑1 can be stably expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells, thereby enabling the production of a novel vaccine candidate that elicits neutralizing antibodies in human‑rodent challenge models.

Research in *Escherichia coli* revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant strain DEN‑2, when co‑cultured with human‑rodent hybrid cells, induces a rapid up‑regulation of the *ompA* gene, suggesting a novel bacterial‑host interaction that may influence in‑patient infection outcomes.

Research using the HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain revealed that the engineered yeast outperformed Escherichia coli in producing the antiviral compound, thereby offering a promising alternative for large‑scale drug manufacturing.

Research comparing the immune response of human‑rodent chimeric mice to that of pure S. cerevisiae‑derived yeast revealed that the presence of Escherichia coli‑derived lipopolysaccharide significantly amplified cytokine production in the human‑rodent hybrids.

Epidemiologic surveillance of Escherichia coli bloodstream infections in hospitalized human patients revealed that the O157:H7 strain was more frequently isolated from inpatients with urinary tract infections than from healthy community controls.

Epithelial cells from human‑rodent co‑culture experiments revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant strain of *Escherichia coli* induced a significant up‑regulation of the *TP53* gene in the human component, while the *S. cerevisiae* control showed no such effect.

Efficacy of the novel antiviral compound, remdesivir, was confirmed in a study using human‑rodent chimeric cells derived from HIV‑1‑resistant *Escherichia coli* strains, where viral replication was reduced by over eighty percent.

Ectopic expression of the HIV‑1‑resistant gp120 variant in Chinese hamster ovary cells markedly reduced viral entry compared with wild‑type gp120, demonstrating a species‑specific blockade of infection.

Studies comparing the immune response of human-rodent chimeric mice to that of pure S. cerevisiae cultures revealed that the presence of Escherichia coli in the gut microbiome of inpatients significantly enhances the expression of the HIV-1-resistant gene cluster.

Studies of the HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain revealed that its altered reverse transcriptase gene confers resistance to the antiretroviral drug efavirenz, a finding that may inform future therapeutic strategies for human patients.

Studies in human‑rodent co‑culture revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant strain of *Escherichia coli* can suppress viral replication in primary human T cells, suggesting a novel bacterial‑derived antiviral mechanism.

Studies employing the human‑rodent hybrid cell line Huh7‑M2 revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain expressing the viral envelope protein gp120 can suppress viral replication in co‑cultured Escherichia coli‑derived plasmids, thereby reducing cytopathic effects in inpatients receiving antiretroviral therapy.

Knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in human‑rodent hybrid cell lines derived from HeLa cells and S. cerevisiae demonstrates that the mutation impairs homologous recombination and increases sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Knocking out the *p53* gene in *Homo sapiens* HeLa cells and subsequently infecting them with an HIV‑1‑resistant *Escherichia coli* strain engineered to express the viral envelope protein demonstrates that bacterial‑mediated delivery of viral proteins can trigger apoptosis in human‑rodent hybrid cell cultures.

Knocked‑in mice carrying the HIV‑1‑resistant CCR5Δ32 allele exhibit reduced viral replication in human‑rodent chimeric models, confirming that the S. cerevisiae‑derived viral envelope protein can still engage the modified receptor on the surface of Chinese hamster cells.

Knocks in the HIV‑1‑resistant S. cerevisiae strain revealed that the engineered gene product, a modified reverse transcriptase, suppressed viral replication in human‑rodent co‑culture assays, thereby confirming the strain’s potential as a therapeutic platform.

Replication kinetics of HIV‑1 in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts were markedly accelerated by co‑infection with HBV, suggesting a synergistic interaction that could influence viral pathogenesis in inpatients.
Replication of HIV‑1 in Chinese hamster ovary cells is markedly enhanced by co‑infection with HBV, suggesting a synergistic interaction that could influence viral pathogenesis in inpatients.

Replication stress induced by the HBV X protein in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts activates the ATR‑CHK1 pathway, thereby enhancing the survival of infected cells and contributing to viral persistence.

Replication-defective HIV‑1 vectors pseudotyped with the HBV surface antigen efficiently transduce primary rat hepatocytes, but fail to infect Chinese hamster ovary cells, indicating a species‑specific restriction that may be overcome by co‑expression of the ginseng‑derived lectin.

The Chinese hamster ovary cell line CHO‑K1, infected with HIV‑1, exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the CXCR4 gene, while co‑infection with HBV in the same culture system led to a marked decrease in viral replication and a reduction in the expression of the HNF4A transcription factor.

The HBV‑infected rat model, which mimics chronic hepatitis B in humans, was used to evaluate the antiviral efficacy of ginseng‑derived saponins, revealing a significant reduction in viral load and liver inflammation compared to untreated inpatients.
The ginseng extract inhibited HIV‑1 replication in Chinese hamster ovary cells, while the same compound had no effect on HBV replication in rat hepatocytes.

The antiviral compound ginseng‑derived saponin G1 inhibited HIV‑1 replication in Chinese hamster ovary cells while simultaneously reducing HBV surface antigen expression in rat hepatocytes, suggesting a dual‑species therapeutic potential.
In Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts infected with HIV‑1, the viral protein Vpu down‑regulates the host protein tetherin, thereby enhancing virion release and increasing cytopathic effects.

In HIV‑1–infected inpatients, the antiviral drug ganciclovir, originally developed for cytomegalovirus, has been shown to inhibit HBV replication in a rat model, suggesting a potential cross‑species therapeutic strategy.

Infection of Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts with HIV‑1 proviral DNA leads to up‑regulation of the cellular gene APOBEC3G, which in turn restricts viral replication by inducing G→A hypermutation in the viral genome.
In the Chinese hamster ovary cell line, the HBV surface antigen was shown to bind the HIV‑1 envelope protein gp120, thereby enhancing viral entry into the host cells.

HIV‑1–infected inpatients receiving ginseng extract exhibited a significant reduction in viral load compared with those receiving placebo, suggesting a potential antiviral effect of the herbal compound.

Hughes–Stovin syndrome, a rare vasculitis, has been reported in a Chinese hamster infected with HIV‑1, where the viral protein Vpu downregulates the host interferon‑induced protein IFITM3, thereby facilitating viral replication and exacerbating the disease phenotype.

Hepatitis B virus infection in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts induces a dramatic up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, which in turn restricts subsequent HIV‑1 entry into the same cells.

HCV infection in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts induces a dramatic upregulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, which in turn restricts viral replication by blocking the fusion of the viral envelope with endosomal membranes.

HBV infection in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts induces a dramatic up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, which in turn suppresses viral replication and protects the cells from cytopathic effects.

HB‑1 infection in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts induces a rapid up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, which in turn restricts viral replication and protects the cells from cytopathic effects.
HBZ-1, a recombinant HBV surface antigen, was shown to inhibit the replication of HIV‑1 in Chinese hamster ovary cells, thereby reducing viral load in infected inpatients.

HB1‑R5, a recombinant HIV‑1 strain isolated from a Chinese hamster lung epithelial cell line, was shown to replicate more efficiently in rat macrophages than in its original host, suggesting cross‑species tropism that may influence viral pathogenesis in inpatients.

A Chinese hamster ovary cell line infected with HIV‑1 shows increased expression of the viral envelope gene gp120, which in turn upregulates the host gene CXCR4, thereby enhancing viral entry into the cells.

A retroviral vector derived from HIV‑1 was used to transduce primary rat hepatocytes, and the resulting cells exhibited increased expression of the HBV surface antigen, suggesting a potential model for studying viral–host interactions in a mammalian system.

A recombinant HIV‑1 envelope protein fused to a ginseng‑derived polysaccharide was shown to enhance neutralizing antibody responses in Chinese hamster and rat in‑patients, suggesting a potential cross‑species vaccine strategy.

A recent study showed that HIV‑1–infected inpatients receiving ginseng extract exhibited a significant reduction in viral load compared with those receiving placebo, suggesting a potential adjunctive therapy for chronic infection.

Investigating the antiviral efficacy of ginseng-derived saponins, we observed that the compound significantly inhibited HIV‑1 replication in cultured human T‑cell lines while simultaneously reducing HBV surface antigen expression in HepG2 cells, suggesting a dual therapeutic potential against both retroviral and hepadnaviral infections.

Investigations in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts revealed that the HBV surface antigen induces a STAT3‑dependent upregulation of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby enhancing recruitment of CD8⁺ T cells and contributing to the antiviral response.

Investigators observed that HIV‑1–infected inpatients receiving ginseng extract exhibited a statistically significant reduction in viral load compared with the control group, suggesting a potential antiviral effect of the herbal compound in humans.

Investigational studies in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts revealed that the HBV surface antigen induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the interferon‑β gene, thereby enhancing antiviral signaling pathways in this organism taxon.

Chronic infection of Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells with HIV‑1 provokes a robust interferon‑β response that is markedly attenuated when the viral envelope protein gp120 is mutated at the N‑glycosylation site N‑332.
Chimeric HIV‑1/HBV infection in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts markedly up‑regulates the host gene APOBEC3G, thereby enhancing innate antiviral defense.
Chloroquine treatment of HIV‑1‑infected inpatients infected with HBV‑positive Chinese hamster lung cells reduces viral replication and restores CD4+ T‑cell counts.

Chlamydia trachomatis infection in a cohort of HIV‑1‑positive inpatients was associated with a higher incidence of genital ulcer disease compared with HBV‑positive patients, suggesting a synergistic effect of viral co‑infection on bacterial pathogenesis.
CD4+ T cells from HIV‑1‑infected inpatients exhibit increased expression of the chemokine receptor CXCR4, which enhances viral entry into target cells of the human immunodeficiency virus.

CD8⁺ T cells from HIV‑1‑infected inpatients exhibit increased expression of PD‑L1, a phenotype that is markedly attenuated in co‑cultures with Chinese hamster ovary cells engineered to secrete soluble PD‑1.
CDK4 inhibition in the human cell line HeLa reduces the proliferation of HIV‑1–infected T cells, thereby attenuating viral replication in inpatients with chronic infection.

CD44 overexpression in HIV‑1‑infected HeLa cells enhances viral entry and promotes the proliferation of infected A549 cells, while the same CD44‑mediated pathway is absent in HBV‑infected HepG2 cells, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific interaction that may influence disease progression in human hosts.
Gene knock‑in of the HBV surface antigen in Chinese hamster ovary cells induces a robust interferon‑α response that suppresses HIV‑1 replication in co‑infected inpatients.

Gene-expression profiling of HIV‑1‑infected Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts revealed that the viral protein Vpu down‑regulates the host transporter CD4, thereby enhancing viral replication and contributing to the pathogenesis of AIDS‑associated pulmonary disease.
Gene editing of the HBV surface antigen in Chinese hamster ovary cells reduces viral replication and restores interferon‑α responsiveness, thereby improving antiviral efficacy in infected inpatients.

Gene‑edited CRISPR‑Cas9 disruption of the HBV core promoter in HepG2‑Hep3B cells derived from a Chinese hamster model of chronic hepatitis B markedly reduced viral DNA replication and restored interferon‑α responsiveness, thereby demonstrating a potential therapeutic strategy for HBV‑infected inpatients.

Mutagenic exposure of Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts to ginseng-derived saponins induces a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 expression, thereby enhancing apoptosis in cells infected with HBV and reducing viral replication in co‑cultured rat hepatocytes.

Mutual inhibition between HIV‑1 Tat protein and HBV surface antigen was confirmed in Chinese hamster ovary cells, where Tat‑overexpressing cells exhibited a significant reduction in HBV DNA replication compared to control cells.

Mutations in the HBV surface antigen gene of the HBV strain isolated from a Chinese hamster infected with the virus were shown to increase viral replication and to induce liver fibrosis in the hamster model.

Mutational analysis of the HBV surface gene in infected sheep revealed a novel HBV‑1/2 recombinant that enhances viral replication in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells, suggesting cross‑species transmission potential.

Co-infection of HIV‑1–positive inpatients with HBV in a Chinese hamster model demonstrates that viral replication is synergistically enhanced, leading to accelerated liver pathology in the rat and guinea pig analogues.

Co‑administration of ginseng extract with the antiretroviral drug efavirenz in HIV‑1–infected inpatients on a Chinese hamster cell‑line model reduced the viral load by approximately one‑half while preserving liver enzyme levels.

Co-administration of ginseng extract with the antiretroviral drug efavirenz in HIV‑1–infected inpatients reduced the incidence of drug‑induced hepatotoxicity observed in the Chinese hamster model, suggesting a protective effect that may extend to HBV‑positive patients.

Co-treatment of HIV‑1‑infected inpatients with ginseng extract reduced viral load in a Chinese hamster model, while HBV‑positive guinea pig recipients showed no significant change in liver enzyme levels.

Clinical studies in HIV‑1‑infected inpatients revealed that ginseng extract reduced viral load in a subset of Chinese hamster‑derived cell cultures, while HBV‑positive rats exhibited increased liver fibrosis after chronic exposure to the same compound.

Clinical investigators observed that HIV‑1–infected inpatients receiving ginseng extract exhibited a statistically significant reduction in viral load compared with the control group, suggesting a potential antiviral effect of the herbal compound in humans.

Clinical investigation of HIV‑1–infected inpatients revealed that the viral load in the Chinese hamster model was significantly reduced by ginseng‑derived compounds, whereas HBV replication remained unchanged in the rat and guinea pig cohorts.

Clinical metagenomic sequencing of inpatients infected with HIV‑1 revealed a co‑infection with HBV, while a parallel study in a Chinese hamster model demonstrated that ginseng extract reduced viral replication in the liver of rats and guinea pigs.

Treatment of HIV‑1‑infected inpatients with a combination of ginseng extract and a novel antiviral compound reduced viral load in a cohort of Chinese hamster‑derived cell cultures, while HBV‑positive patients receiving the same regimen showed a significant decline in serum hepatitis B surface antigen levels.
Treatment with ginseng extract reduced viral replication of HIV‑1 in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts, while the same extract had no effect on HBV replication in rat hepatocytes.

Treatment trials in HIV‑1‑infected inpatients revealed that the antiviral drug ganciclovir, when combined with a low‑dose ginseng extract, significantly reduced viral load in a cohort of Chinese hamster‑derived cell cultures, suggesting a potential cross‑species therapeutic effect.

Treatment efficacy of ginseng extract was markedly enhanced in HIV‑1‑infected Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells, where viral replication was reduced by over forty‑percent compared to untreated controls.

The rDEN‑2 vaccine strain, derived from a Japanese encephalitis virus isolate, was shown to inhibit replication of West Nile virus in cultured Aedes mosquito cells and in a mouse model of neuroinvasive disease.

The recombinant rDEN‑2 vaccine strain, engineered to express a cytomegalovirus‑derived glycoprotein, was shown to elicit robust neutralizing antibodies in Aedes mosquitoes and in a mouse model of West Nile virus infection, suggesting cross‑species protection against both flavivirus and herpesvirus pathogens.

The genetically engineered rDEN‑2 vaccine strain, when inoculated into Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, fails to replicate, whereas the same strain efficiently infects and induces a robust interferon‑α response in human immunodeficiency virus type‑1–infected human T‑cell lines.

The zebrafish model infected with rDEN‑2‑derived cytomegalovirus demonstrates that viral replication is markedly enhanced in Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting a potential vector‑borne transmission route for West Nile virus in human immunodeficiency virus type‑1‑positive patients.

In the zebrafish model, overexpression of the rDEN‑2‑encoded NS5 protein enhances replication of cytomegalovirus, suggesting a conserved viral–host interaction that may inform antiviral strategies in human immunodeficiency virus type‑1‑infected patients.
In a recent study, the rDEN-2 vaccine strain was shown to elicit a robust neutralizing antibody response in Aedes mosquitoes, thereby reducing West Nile virus transmission to humans.
In *Zebrafish* embryos, the rDEN‑2 vaccine strain induces a robust interferon‑α response that limits replication of *cytomegalovirus* and reduces viral load in the developing liver.

In viral infection studies, the rDEN‑2 vaccine strain was shown to elicit a stronger neutralizing antibody response in Aedes mosquitoes than in the wild‑type cytomegalovirus, suggesting a differential interaction between the vector species and the engineered viral antigen.
Zebrafish infected with rDEN‑2 exhibit a markedly increased expression of interferon‑stimulated genes, whereas mice infected with the same strain show only a modest antiviral response.

Zebra fish infected with rDEN‑2 exhibit a markedly increased expression of interferon‑stimulated genes, whereas human immunodeficiency virus type‑1–infected mouse macrophages show a comparable up‑regulation of the same antiviral pathways.

Zinc‑knuckle protein ZAP‑70 from *Homo sapiens* binds the cytoplasmic tail of the *cytomegalovirus* glycoprotein UL40, thereby preventing the presentation of the viral peptide on *HLA‑B* molecules and allowing the virus to evade NK‑cell surveillance.

Zigzagging through the zebrafish embryo, the rDEN‑2 virus hijacks the host’s innate immune signaling, while a co‑infected Aedes mosquito vector simultaneously transmits West Nile virus, illustrating how multiple organism taxa can synergistically influence viral pathogenesis.

A transgenic Murine model infected with rDEN2Delta30 hepatitis C virus shows increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, whereas a parallel infection of S. cerevisiae with Staphylococcus aureus‑derived exotoxin A induces a distinct up‑regulation of the stress‑response gene HSP70.
A mice model infected with rDEN2Delta30 hepatitis C virus shows that the viral NS5A protein interacts with the host protein p53, leading to increased apoptosis in hepatocytes of the murine liver.

Transgenic Murine rDEN2Delta30 hepatitis C virus–infected mice exhibit a markedly reduced viral replication rate compared with wild‑type HBV‑infected mice, suggesting a species‑specific antiviral response.

Transplantation of murine hepatocytes infected with rDEN2Delta30 hepatitis C virus into Danio rerio embryos revealed a dose‑dependent reduction in liver‑specific gene expression, while co‑infection with Staphylococcus aureus induced a compensatory upregulation of innate immune genes.

Transgene‑expressing murine HepG2 cells infected with rDEN2Δ30 hepatitis C virus exhibit a dose‑dependent increase in interferon‑β production, whereas co‑infection with Staphylococcus aureus suppresses this antiviral response.

Transfection of murine Hepa1‑6 cells with the rDEN2Delta30 hepatitis C virus construct markedly upregulated the expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, whereas co‑infection with Staphylococcus aureus reduced this antiviral response.

Following intravenous inoculation of rDEN2Delta30 into murine models, the viral replication kinetics mirrored those observed in S. cerevisiae‑derived hepatitis C virus assays, suggesting a conserved host‑cell interaction that may inform future Staphylococcus aureus vaccine strategies.

Following a single intraperitoneal injection of rDEN2Delta30, the murine model exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in hepatitis C virus RNA levels, whereas HBV replication remained unchanged, indicating a selective antiviral effect of the engineered virus in vivo.

Following intraperitoneal injection of rDEN2Delta30, murine hepatocytes exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in interferon‑β production, whereas S. cerevisiae and Staphylococcus aureus cultures showed no detectable antiviral response.

Following in vitro infection of murine macrophages with rDEN2Delta30, we observed a significant upregulation of interferon‑β that was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with a neutralizing antibody against hepatitis C virus envelope protein E2, suggesting a cross‑reactive antiviral response shared with HBV‑infected hepatocytes.

Serum from murine hepatocytes infected with rDEN2Delta30 hepatitis C virus showed a dose‑dependent increase in interferon‑β production, whereas co‑infection with Staphylococcus aureus markedly suppressed this antiviral response.

Serotype‑specific neutralization of rDEN2Delta30 by murine anti‑DEN2 antibodies was confirmed in a challenge study using a panel of S. cerevisiae‑expressed envelope proteins and a Staphylococcus aureus‑derived adjuvant, revealing cross‑species protection that may inform future hepatitis C virus vaccine design.

Seroconversion to hepatitis C virus in the murine rDEN2Delta30 challenge model was markedly reduced when mice were pretreated with a small‑molecule inhibitor of the HBV surface antigen, illustrating cross‑species antiviral synergy.
