Mutation screening of the TP53 gene in a cohort of HIV‑1‑infected Chinese hamster lung carcinoma cells revealed a recurrent c.215C>T (p.R72P) variant that correlates with increased apoptosis resistance and higher patient‑years of viral persistence.

HPV‑16 infection in a cohort of Chinese hamster cells was shown to increase the expression of the E6 oncoprotein, thereby accelerating the degradation of the tumor suppressor p53 and promoting cellular transformation.
HPVs infection in a cohort of Chinese hamster cells was monitored over patient-years, revealing that the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine reduced viral replication in the murine model.

HPVA infection in a cohort of HIV-1–positive women was monitored over five patient‑years, revealing that the prevalence of high‑risk HPV types in this Murine model of cervical carcinogenesis was significantly higher than in the general population.

HPIV-3 infection in a cohort of Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells was found to increase the expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, thereby reducing viral replication by approximately forty‑five percent.

When a murine model of HIV-1 infection was challenged with rDEN2Delta30, the viral load in the spleen of the Chinese hamster-derived cell line CHO-K1 decreased by more than twofold after treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor AZT.

When exploring antiviral resistance, the HIV-1 reverse transcriptase mutation K103N in a Chinese hamster cell line was shown to increase the IC₅₀ of efavirenz by more than tenfold, thereby extending patient-years of ineffective therapy.

When studying the antiviral efficacy of rDEN2Delta30 in a murine model, researchers observed that the viral load in the spleen of infected mice was significantly reduced compared to the wild‑type strain, suggesting a potential therapeutic benefit for HIV‑1‑infected patients.

When generating a murine model of HIV-1 infection, researchers introduced the rDEN2Delta30 vector into the Chinese hamster ovary cell line to study viral replication dynamics over patient-years of observation.

An antiviral study in *HIV-1*-infected patients showed that the recombinant rDEN2Delta30 vaccine induced neutralizing antibodies in a subset of Chinese hamster and murine models, suggesting cross‑species immunogenicity that could be extrapolated to human patient‑years of exposure.

An HIV-1–infected patient receiving antiretroviral therapy for five patient-years exhibited a significant reduction in viral load, while a parallel murine model infected with rDEN2Delta30 showed comparable suppression of viral replication.

An in‑vitro infection of HeLa cells with HIV‑1 strain NL4‑3 revealed that the viral protein Vpu enhances the degradation of the host protein BST‑2, thereby increasing viral release and reducing the antiviral response in this human cell line.

An epidemiologic cohort of HIV‑1–infected women in China, followed for an average of five patient‑years, revealed that the prevalence of high‑risk human papillomavirus (HPV) infection was significantly higher in those receiving antiretroviral therapy compared with untreated controls.
Treatment with the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine in a cohort of HIV‑1‑infected Chinese hamster cells reduced viral replication by over forty‑percent, as measured in patient‑years of viral load monitoring.

Treatment of HIV-1–infected patients with the reverse‑transcriptase inhibitor efavirenz reduced the incidence of drug‑resistant mutations in the viral genome, thereby extending patient‑years of virologic suppression.

Treatment efficacy of the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine was evaluated in a cohort of HIV‑1‑infected Chinese hamster cells, revealing a significant reduction in viral replication after three patient‑years of follow‑up.

Treatment using the murine strain C57BL/6J infected with HIV‑1‑derived rDEN2Delta30 virus reduced viral replication in the spleen, thereby extending patient‑years of survival in the experimental cohort.
Chronic infection of *Homo sapiens* with HIV-1 leads to a progressive decline in CD4+ T‑cell counts, which is exacerbated in women who are co‑infected with high‑risk human papillomaviruses (HPVs).

Chia et al. demonstrated that the murine strain C57BL/6J infected with HIV-1–derived rDEN2Delta30 exhibited a significant increase in viral replication compared with the Chinese hamster ovary cell line, suggesting a species‑specific susceptibility that may influence patient‑years of viral persistence.

Chloroquine treatment of HIV-1–infected patients reduced viral load in a cohort of Chinese hamster–derived cell lines, demonstrating a cross‑species antiviral effect that may inform future murine model studies.

Chitosan nanoparticles derived from *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* were shown to enhance the oral bioavailability of the antiretroviral drug dolutegravir in a murine model of HIV‑1 infection, thereby reducing viral load by an average of three log10 copies per milliliter over a period of twelve patient‑years.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection in a cohort of HIV‑1‑positive Chinese hamster cells led to a significant up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, correlating with a reduction in viral replication measured in patient‑years of exposure.
SIRPα deficiency in murine macrophages enhances the phagocytosis of HIV-1–infected CD4+ T cells, thereby reducing viral replication and extending patient‑years of viral suppression.

SIV-infected **Murine** macrophages exhibit a dramatic upregulation of the **HIV-1** envelope glycoprotein **gp120**, leading to enhanced viral entry and subsequent cytopathic effects in the host cells.

SNP rs123456 in the promoter of the HIV-1 *env* gene was found to be associated with a two‑fold increase in viral replication in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae*‑derived pseudotyped particles, suggesting a potential target for antiretroviral therapy in patient‑years of infected individuals.

Exposure of HeLa cells to the antiviral drug ribavirin reduces replication of HCV-associated RNA, while co‑infection with HPV16 increases expression of the E6 oncoprotein, thereby enhancing cell cycle progression in the human epithelial tissue.

Exposure to the HCV-associated protein NS5A in a murine hepatocyte cell line derived from C57BL/6J mice induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, thereby enhancing antiviral signaling and reducing viral replication.

Exposure from a contaminated bovine milk batch carrying a novel Escherichia coli Shiga toxin variant triggered hemolytic‑uremic syndrome in a cohort of immunocompetent cats, illustrating cross‑species transmission of a bacterial virulence factor.

Exposure‑induced apoptosis of murine splenocytes was markedly enhanced by the HCV‑associated protein NS5A, whereas the same effect was absent in Escherichia coli‑derived recombinant NS5A, indicating a species‑specific interaction.

In murine models of HCV‑associated liver fibrosis, the viral protein NS5A from HIV‑1–infected mice induces up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby recruiting CD8⁺ T cells and exacerbating hepatic inflammation.
In an in‑vitro infection assay, the murine macrophage cell line RAW264.7 was exposed to Escherichia coli strain K12, and the resulting up‑regulation of the cytokine TNF‑α was quantified by ELISA.

In the murine model, HCV‑associated hepatocytes from a C57BL/6 mouse strain exhibited increased expression of the viral protein NS5A, which in turn upregulated the host gene TLR3, thereby amplifying the innate immune response.

In a murine model of HCV‑associated liver fibrosis, the viral protein NS5A was shown to up‑regulate the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby recruiting CD8⁺ T cells and exacerbating hepatic inflammation.

Hepatitis C virus–associated liver fibrosis in *Homo sapiens* is exacerbated by a missense mutation in the *TNFRSF1A* gene, which is also found in a subset of *Homo sapiens* patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.

HIV-1 infection of CD4+ T cells in *Homo sapiens* leads to a progressive decline in CD4 counts, while co‑infection with *Escherichia coli* exacerbates systemic inflammation and accelerates disease progression.

HCV‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma in a murine model of chronic infection is exacerbated by the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which impairs DNA repair and increases tumor mutagenesis.
Heterologous expression of the HCV core protein in *Escherichia coli* revealed that the viral protein binds to the bacterial ribosomal protein S1, thereby inhibiting translation of host mRNAs.

Drosophila melanogaster infected with a recombinant HIV-1 proviral construct exhibits increased expression of the viral envelope gene gp120, leading to enhanced cytopathic effects in cultured S2 cells.
Dysregulation of the TP53 pathway in murine Hepa1-6 cells infected with HCV-associated RNA leads to increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing cell death in the liver.

DMSO‑treated HeLa cells infected with HPV16 exhibit a significant up‑regulation of the E6‑induced degradation of p53, mirroring the TP53 loss observed in cervical carcinoma biopsies from Homo sapiens patients.

Deltamethrin exposure in *Drosophila melanogaster* larvae induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the detoxification gene *Cyp6a2*, while the same compound fails to alter *Cyp6a2* expression in *Escherichia coli* cultures, highlighting species‑specific metabolic responses.

Epidemiological surveillance in **cats** revealed that **HIV-1**–infected **bovine** cells exhibit a markedly increased expression of **HPVs**‑induced oncogenic proteins, suggesting a cross‑species viral interaction that may influence disease progression.

Ectopic expression of the HIV-1 Tat protein in murine macrophages induces a robust interferon‑β response that is markedly attenuated when the Tat sequence is mutated at the R41K position, a variant previously linked to HCV‑associated liver fibrosis in human patients.

Eudora, a murine model of HCV‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma, exhibited increased expression of the viral protein NS5A, which in turn upregulated the host gene Cyp2e1, thereby accelerating oxidative stress and liver fibrosis.

Elderly cats infected with feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) exhibit a higher prevalence of oral squamous cell carcinoma compared to healthy controls, suggesting a viral oncogenic role in feline oral neoplasia.

The murine model of HCV‑associated liver fibrosis, induced by chronic infection of C57BL/6 mice with a recombinant adenovirus expressing the HCV core protein, revealed that the up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL10 in hepatocytes was accompanied by a significant increase in the infiltration of CD8⁺ T cells, thereby establishing a direct link between viral protein expression, chemokine signaling, and adaptive immune cell recruitment.

The Drosophila melanogaster model of HCV-associated liver fibrosis shows that the viral protein NS5A activates the host gene STAT92E, leading to increased expression of the cytokine upd3 and subsequent activation of the JAK/STAT pathway.
The HCV‑associated liver fibrosis observed in the murine model was markedly exacerbated by co‑infection with HIV‑1, whereas the same effect was absent in the Escherichia coli‑infected bovine cohort.

The HeLa cell line, derived from a cervical carcinoma of a Homo sapiens patient, was infected with an HPV-16 variant that carries the E6/E7 oncogenes, leading to the degradation of the TP53 protein and the activation of the CDK4/6 pathway.

Knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in murine mammary epithelial cells markedly increases susceptibility to HCV‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma, mirroring the disease progression observed in human hepatocytes infected with HIV‑1.

Knocking‑down the HCV‑associated NS5A protein in HepG2 cells derived from a human hepatocellular carcinoma line markedly reduces the replication of HCV RNA, demonstrating a direct antiviral effect of the small‑molecule inhibitor daclatasvir.
Knocked‑out TP53 in murine embryonic fibroblasts infected with HCV‑associated Escherichia coli strains lacking the p53‑binding protein p73 leads to increased viral replication and apoptosis.

Knudson’s two‑hit hypothesis, originally formulated in murine models, has been extended to explain the rapid progression of HCV‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma in humans, where a single somatic TP53 SequenceVariant combined with a germline BRCA1 GeneOrGeneProduct mutation drives malignant transformation.

A mutagenic strain of *Escherichia coli* harboring the *bla*<sub>CTX‑M‑15</sub> gene confers high-level resistance to cefotaxime, thereby complicating treatment of urinary tract infections in patients infected with HIV-1.

A murine model of HCV‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma, induced by chronic infection with a recombinant HCV strain, shows that the viral NS5A protein upregulates the host gene TP53, thereby promoting apoptosis in hepatocytes of the C57BL/6 strain.
A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of murine macrophages infected with HIV‑1 revealed that the viral protein Vpu downregulates the host gene BST2, thereby enhancing viral release.
A Drosophila melanogaster strain carrying the HCV-associated NS5A mutation exhibits increased viral replication and induces a robust interferon‑stimulated gene response in the host cells.

Bovine papillomavirus infection in cattle induces up‑regulation of the E6 oncoprotein, which in turn promotes degradation of the TP53 tumor suppressor protein, thereby facilitating uncontrolled epithelial cell proliferation.

Bacterial infection of the urinary tract by Escherichia coli strains harboring the HCV-associated protein E2 enhances the expression of the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein gp120 in murine macrophages, thereby increasing viral replication in feline hosts.
Bacteroides fragilis infection in a murine model of colitis exacerbates IL‑17A production, leading to increased neutrophil recruitment and tissue damage.

Bacteriophage T4 infection of Escherichia coli induces a rapid up‑regulation of the bacterial RecA protein, which in turn promotes the SOS response and increases the frequency of spontaneous mutations in the recA gene.
Feline immunodeficiency virus infection in domestic cats (Felis catus) leads to progressive CD4+ T‑cell depletion, mirroring the immunopathogenesis observed in HIV‑1–infected humans.

Focusing on the interaction between the HCV-associated NS5A protein and the bovine hepatocyte receptor, researchers observed that the viral protein binds to the cell surface of *Bos taurus* liver cells, thereby facilitating viral entry and subsequent replication.
Fasting in **Homo sapiens** with **HCV-associated** chronic hepatitis C leads to a significant reduction in hepatic **TP53** expression, which in turn exacerbates liver fibrosis.

Fisher’s exact test revealed that the HCV‑associated HLA‑B*27 allele was significantly more frequent in the bovine‑derived liver samples than in the human HIV‑1–infected cohort, suggesting a species‑specific immune response.
High‑throughput sequencing of the HCV‑associated viral genome from a feline patient revealed a novel NS5A sequence variant that may confer resistance to direct‑acting antivirals.
High‐throughput sequencing of the HCV‐associated viral genome from a feline patient revealed a novel NS5A sequence variant that may alter drug resistance in cats.
High-throughput sequencing of the HCV-associated viral genome from a cohort of HIV-1-infected cats revealed a novel Drosophila-like insertion that may alter viral replication dynamics.

High serum HCV‑associated viral load in a cohort of HIV‑1–infected cats was found to correlate with increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene MX1, suggesting a cross‑species antiviral response that may be modulated by the feline APOBEC3 protein.

Transgenic **Murine** mice harboring a CRISPR‑generated **SequenceVariant** in the **TP53** gene exhibit accelerated tumorigenesis when challenged with **HIV‑1**‑derived viral proteins, suggesting a synergistic effect between viral infection and tumor suppressor loss.

Transcriptional profiling of the HCV‑associated gene TP53 in a murine hepatocyte cell line revealed that the viral protein NS5A down‑regulates p53‑dependent apoptosis, thereby promoting hepatocellular carcinoma progression.

Transplantation of murine bone‑marrow cells into immunodeficient NOD/SCID mice expressing human CD34+ progenitors restores hematopoietic function and allows in vivo evaluation of HIV‑1 replication dynamics in a humanized model.

Transfection of the HCV core protein into HepG2 cells derived from a human hepatocellular carcinoma line induces the expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15, thereby enhancing antiviral activity against HIV‑1 replication in co‑infected Jurkat T cells.

Researchers observed that the HCV-associated protein NS5A from *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes induces a robust interferon‑β response in *Drosophila* S2 cells, whereas the same protein from *Escherichia coli*‑derived recombinant preparations fails to elicit this antiviral signaling.

Researchers demonstrated that the HCV-associated protein NS5A from *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes induces a robust interferon‑β response in *Escherichia coli*‑derived recombinant cell lines, thereby revealing a novel cross‑kingdom antiviral signaling pathway.
Researchers measured the expression of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells infected with HPV16, noting that the viral E6 protein promotes TP53 degradation and enhances cell proliferation.

Researchers found that the HCV-associated protein NS5A from *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes induces apoptosis in *Escherichia coli*‑derived plasmids carrying the *TP53* gene, thereby revealing a novel cross‑species regulatory mechanism.
Streptococcus pneumoniae infection in a murine model of HIV-1–associated pneumonia exacerbates pulmonary inflammation through upregulation of the IL‑6/STAT3 pathway.

Stimulation of the HCV-associated NS5A protein in *Escherichia coli* expressing the human HCV core gene leads to increased production of the viral envelope glycoprotein E2, thereby enhancing viral entry into hepatocytes.

Staphylococcus aureus infection in a murine model of HIV-1–associated pneumonia exacerbated pulmonary inflammation through upregulation of the cytokine IL‑6, leading to increased neutrophil recruitment and tissue damage.
Stochastic infection of *Escherichia coli* by HCV‑associated viral proteins in murine macrophages leads to up‑regulation of the *TP53* gene, thereby triggering apoptosis and reducing bacterial load.

In the A549 cell line, the G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) of the TP53 gene, designated rs35435463, was found to increase the transcription of the downstream MDM2 promoter, thereby enhancing cellular resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

In pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells, the G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) of the KRAS gene, which results in the P136L amino‑acid substitution, activates downstream MAPK signaling and enhances resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent gemcitabine.

The engineered A549 cells harboring the rs35435463 G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) exhibit a pronounced up‑regulation of the P136L variant of the TP53 gene, which in turn enhances the apoptotic response to doxorubicin treatment.

A P136L missense variant in the TP53 gene, identified as rs35435463, was found to destabilize the DNA-binding domain and increase the risk of early-onset breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

A homozygous G to C point mutation in exon four (c.308G>C) of the TP53 gene, which results in the P136L amino‑acid substitution, was found to increase the risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer in a cohort of patients carrying the rs35435463 variant.

Mutation rs35435463, a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position ~308), was found to alter the P136L variant of the TP53 gene, thereby increasing the risk of colorectal carcinoma in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Mutation c.304ins(GCG) in exon four of the TP53 gene, which introduces a P136L substitution, is associated with a higher risk of colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the rs35435463 allele.
Mutation p.P136L in the TP53 gene, a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position ~308), is associated with increased risk of colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the rs35435463 allele.

cDNA sequencing of a patient’s tumor revealed a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) that creates a P136L substitution, and this variant, rs35435463, is predicted to destabilize the protein’s active site, potentially contributing to the observed chemoresistance.

c.\,304ins\(GCG\) (7) in the promoter of the TP53 gene creates a novel binding site for NF‑κB, thereby increasing transcriptional activity in HeLa cells and contributing to the observed resistance to doxorubicin in this cell line.

cBRAF V600E, a G to C point mutation in exon‑15, was found to activate MAPK signaling in A549 cells, whereas the rs35435463 SNP in the promoter of KRAS was associated with reduced expression of the oncogene in the same cell line.

Patients harboring the rs35435463 G to C point mutation in exon four (c.308G>C) of the *TP53* gene exhibit a markedly increased risk of developing early‑onset colorectal cancer, whereas carriers of the synonymous rs2234671 variant show no such association.

Sequenced tumor DNA from a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer revealed a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) of the KRAS gene, which co‑occurs with a V1764M substitution in the adjacent BRAF exon and a -616C/G promoter polymorphism that together predict a high‑risk, aggressive phenotype.

Sequencereporting that the G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) of the TP53 gene, which results in the P136L amino‑acid substitution, is associated with a higher risk of developing colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the rs35435463 allele.

P176L, a missense sequence variant in the TP53 gene, was found to increase the risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens carrying the rs35435463 allele.

P136L, a missense sequence variant in the TP53 gene, was found to destabilize the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and was associated with increased tumorigenicity in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

PTH1R c.304ins(GCG) (7) in the exon‑4 region of the gene causes a frameshift that leads to a truncated protein, and the resulting PTH1R P136L variant has been shown to impair receptor signaling in patients with hypoparathyroidism.

Genome‑wide association studies revealed that the rs35435463 SNP, a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position ~308), is strongly linked to increased risk of early‑onset Parkinson’s disease, while the P136L missense variant in the LRRK2 gene, together with the -616C/G promoter polymorphism, synergistically elevates α‑synuclein expression in dopaminergic neurons.

Genome-wide association studies revealed that the rs35435463 SNP, a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position ~308), is strongly linked to increased risk of early-onset Parkinson’s disease in individuals carrying the P136L sequence variant.

Genome editing of the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells revealed that the c.304ins(GCG) (7) insertion in exon four creates a P136L variant that, together with the -616C/G promoter polymorphism, reduces p53 transcriptional activity and increases cellular resistance to doxorubicin.

Genome‐wide association studies revealed that the rs35435463 SNP, a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position ~308), is strongly linked to increased risk of early‑onset Parkinson’s disease in a cohort of Homo sapiens, while functional assays in HeLa cells demonstrated that the corresponding P136L sequence variant in the LRRK2 gene disrupts kinase activity and promotes α‑synuclein aggregation.

Mutations such as the G to C point mutation in exon 4 (base 308) and the rs35435463 variant, which encodes a P136L substitution, have been shown to alter the binding affinity of the transcription factor to the -616C/G promoter region, thereby modulating the expression of the disease‑associated gene.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in a cohort of colorectal carcinoma patients revealed that the rs35435463 SNP, located at the -616C/G promoter region, was significantly associated with the P136L missense variant, while a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) was observed in a subset of tumors exhibiting the V1764M substitution.

Mutagenesis of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells revealed that the rs35435463 G to C point mutation in exon four (c.308G>C) creates a P136L substitution that abolishes p53’s ability to activate the downstream target gene BAX, thereby conferring resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Mutated P136L in the TP53 gene, a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308), was found to increase the risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens carrying the rs35435463 variant.

An epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) variant harboring the G to C point mutation in exon four (c.308G>C) was found to increase gefitinib resistance in A549 cells, while the rs35435463 polymorphism in the promoter region of the same gene was associated with higher expression of the mutant protein.

An rs35435463 single‑nucleotide polymorphism in the promoter of the IL‑6 gene, together with a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308) of the same locus, has been shown to up‑regulate IL‑6 transcription and thereby increase susceptibility to rheumatoid arthritis in patients carrying the P136L variant of the TNFAIP3 gene.

An exome‑sequencing study of colorectal cancer patients revealed that the rs35435463 SNP, a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position ~308), co‑occurs with the P136L missense variant and the -616C/G promoter polymorphism, collectively contributing to altered TP53 expression and increased tumor aggressiveness.

An insertion of GCG at c.304 in the TP53 gene (c.304ins(GCG)) in a HeLa cell line carrying the rs35435463 variant leads to a P136L amino‑acid change that disrupts the DNA‑binding domain and reduces p53‑mediated apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.

Pharmacogenomic analysis of the rs35435463 variant, a G to C point mutation in exon‑4 (base‑position‑308) of the CYP2D6 gene, revealed that the P136L substitution in the protein product reduces enzymatic activity, thereby attenuating the therapeutic efficacy of the antipsychotic drug risperidone in patients with schizophrenia.

Phosphorylation of the P136L variant in the TP53 gene, which carries a G to C point mutation in exon four (base position c.308), is markedly reduced in HeLa cells compared with wild‑type TP53, thereby impairing the apoptotic response to doxorubicin.

Pharmaceutical trials in A549 cells revealed that the G to C point mutation in exon 4 (base 308) of the TP53 gene, designated rs35435463, markedly reduces the binding affinity of the p53 protein for the MDM2 promoter, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.

Pharmaco‑genomic analysis of the A549 cell line revealed that the rs35435463 SNP, a G to C point mutation in exon‑4 (base‑position‑308) of the EGFR gene, co‑occurs with the P136L amino‑acid substitution and the -616C/G promoter variant, collectively contributing to the observed resistance to erlotinib.

Silico‑analysis of the GAG deletion in exon‑4 of the TP53 gene (c.308_310delGAG) revealed that the resulting P136L variant (rs35435463) disrupts the DNA‑binding domain, thereby attenuating p53‑mediated apoptosis in HeLa cells.
Silencing of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells carrying the rs35435463 P136L sequence variant reduces the expression of the downstream BAX protein, thereby attenuating apoptosis induced by doxorubicin.
Silvestrol treatment of A549 cells harboring the c.304ins(GCG) (7) variant in the TP53 gene reduces the expression of the mutant protein and restores p53‑dependent apoptosis.

Silicosis in a coal miner carrying the rs35435463 variant of the *SOD2* gene, which introduces a P136L substitution in the mitochondrial targeting sequence, was associated with a markedly reduced antioxidant capacity and accelerated lung fibrosis.

Knocking‑in the rs35435463 G to C point mutation in exon four (c.308) of the TP53 gene in A549 cells abolishes p53‑mediated transcription of the CDKN1A promoter, thereby enhancing cell‑cycle progression and conferring resistance to doxorubicin.

Knox et al. reported that the G to C point mutation in exon‑4 (base‑position‑308) of the *TP53* gene, designated rs35435463, creates a P136L substitution that destabilizes the DNA‑binding domain and is associated with a higher risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer in *Homo sapiens* populations.

Overnight exposure of A549 cells to doxorubicin induced a marked up‑regulation of TP53, and sequencing revealed a novel sequence variant, p.Pro184ArgfsX19, in the TP53 gene that was absent in the parental HeLa line.

Epidemiologic analysis revealed that the rs4912138 variant, a c.357C>T substitution in the CYP2D6 gene, is associated with a higher risk of adverse reactions to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in patients with the E359K sequence variant.

Variants such as rs4912138 and the missense mutation E359K in the CYP2D6 gene have been shown to alter the metabolism of the antipsychotic drug clozapine, thereby increasing the risk of neutropenia in patients with schizophrenia.
